title: brexit news ireland irish border united ireland northern ireland bbc poll
story: The United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland faces an uncertain future with a growing number of Northern Irish citizens supporting reunification with the Republic.The possibility of a referendum on the creation of a united Ireland is permitted by the Good Friday Agreement, with the UK government agreeing to a vote if public support indicates it could pass.And Northern Irish citizens increasingly appear to support leaving the UK to form a united Ireland, according to a new poll released today which was commissioned by the BBC.The Lucid Talk poll reveals 42.1 percent of those surveyed would vote to join the Republic in a unified Ireland, just three points - the margin of error - behind those who want to remain in the UK. The remainder were undecided.And those aged under 45 showed an even higher level of support for a united Ireland. Those aged 18-45 were 49 percent in favour of a united Ireland, 38 percent in favour of remaining in the UK and 13 percent undecided.Brexit could lead to a united Ireland with support growingThe number of Northern Irish citizens in favour of a united Ireland appears far higher than a poll released last month, which saw the same proposal receive just 21 per cent support.However May&rsquos Ipsos Mori poll was conducted face-to-face while the Lucid Talk poll was conducted online and over the phone, with pollsters believing this could help better represent the &ldquoshy united Ireland voters.The BBC commissioned the most recent LucidTalk poll of 1,686 people, who were interviewed between May 4 and May 10.Support was even higher in Belfast, where a majority of 50.2 per cent said they would support a united Ireland - an &ldquoincredible showing given the city's history, one expert said.Northern Irish political commentator David McCann said the result in Belfast was particularly notable given it hosted the signing of the Ulster Covenant- a document signed by 500,000 people in 1912 in protest at the growing autonomy from Britain given to&nbspIreland. Many signed using their own blood with the creation of the unionist militia the Ulster Volunteers following three months later.Mr McCann of current affairs website Slugger O&rsquoToole tweeted: &ldquoA majority of Belfast would support a UI in the city of the Ulster Covenant. Incredible showing.Support for a united Ireland has surged since the June 2016 Brexit voteMore than a quarter of respondents said they had recently changed their mind in favour of a united Ireland due to Brexit. Ironically the ultra-unionist DUP were the only major political party in Northern Ireland to campaign in favour of Brexit.Twenty-eight percent of respondents said they &ldquoused to support NI staying in the UK but I would now support NI joining the ROI in response to a question on whether Brexit had changed their mind.This could be attributed to the ongoing chaos over the future of the Irish border and the fact Northern Irish citizens voted by a hefty majority of 56 percent to remain in the EU, despite the UK as a whole narrowly voting to leave.&nbspIt comes as Irish taoiseach (prime minister) Leo Varadkar travelled across the border for an historic visit to the Orange Order HQ - the first such visit by a ruling leader of the Republic.Mr Varadkar said he was a &ldquoneighbour not an invader as he spoke outside the Grand Lodge, which is the base for the pro-union and pro-Protestant order.Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland could unite as support for a border poll growsThe taoiseach visited a memorial to Orange Order members killed during the Troubles and was welcomed by the Grand Master of Ireland Edward Stevenson.Mr Stevenson said: &ldquoWe acknowledge this is a significant moment as it is the first time a serving leader of the Republic of Ireland government has visited the headquarters of the Grand Orange Lodge of Ireland.&ldquoAs a cross-border organisation, we welcome the Taoiseach&rsquos direct engagement with our members based in the border counties of the Republic and in so doing, recognising the longstanding cultural identity of the Orange family in the south.&ldquoIt is also important to acknowledge the importance of the Taoiseach paying his respects to those members of our Institution, many of whom served in the security forces, who were murdered by terrorists.&ldquoSuch a gesture should not be underestimated and will, I believe, be deeply appreciated by many relatives of the deceased, and the Orange membership as a whole.

title: david davis brexit theresa may resignation pact
story: The furious Brexit Secretary agreed with Steve Baker and Suella Braverman that should Mrs May go ahead with her plan to dodge a hard border with Northern Ireland, all three would quit on Thursday.Sources dubbed the atmosphere a &ldquotinderbox and referring to the government, told the  &ldquoit felt, for the first time, as if it could all have toppled.The pact was fuelled by Boris Johnson&rsquos leaked remarks about wanting a more &ldquomacho leadership on Brexit, which saw the Home Secretary lock horns with Mrs May when he told her to show more &ldquoguts.Had Mr Davis, Mr Baker and Ms Braverman resigned, the result could have been one of Mrs May&rsquos most vulnerable moments in power.Had Mr Davis, Mr Baker and Ms Braverman resigned, the result would have been catastrophic The furious Brexit Secretary agreed with Steve Baker and Suella Braverman to form a pactThe storm could not have come at a worse time for Mrs May.She has a matter of days to defeat 15 House of Lords amendments to the Bill after they suggested she keep the UK in the EU customs union.The result of which would shackle Britain to the bloc forever.Mrs May also infuriated Brexit-backers by giving her remain-supporting cabinet ministers the first glimpse of her revised plan for avoiding a hard border with Northern Ireland in an attempt to keep them on side.                    Getty1 of 34Theresa May's style in picturesThe new plan would keep the UK tied to the EU for a &ldquotime limited period should she fail to reach a customs deal.Mr Davis was eventually given access to the paperwork and was said to have not liked what he saw as with no date mentioned as to when the backstop would expire, the document did not appear to be &ldquotime limited whatsoever.Mr Davis, Mr Baker and Ms Braverman were said to be so infuriated with the plan they were willing to jack in their results and risk collapsing the government if Mrs May did not out an end date on it.The pact is the second time Brexiteer Mr Davis has threatened to resign.In April, he joined forces with Mr Johnson, Michael Gove and Liam Fox with all four threatening resignation over Mrs May&rsquos desired partnership customs union option.

title: Prince philip birthday pictures how old is prince philip the queen news
story: Prince PhilipThe Duke of Edinburgh has been enjoying a more leisurely time at home in Windsor Castle following his retirement from public duties in August last year after 65 years of public service.Buckingham Palace said Prince Philip will celebrate his birthday in private, just one day after the Queen's official 92nd birthday was marked with all the pomp and pageantry of the Trooping the Colour.&nbspAt the age of 97, Prince Philip is the husband of one of the most famous women in the world after giving up a promising naval career to support his wife in her role.Through the highs and lows of life leading Britain&rsquos much-loved Royal Family, Prince Philip has been there every step of the way for the Queen.And their enduring relationship has lasted the longest of any British sovereign.                Royal family tragedy as Queen Maxima&rsquos sister found dead aged 33The Duke of Edinburgh vowed to act as Queen Elizabeth&rsquos &ldquoeyes and ears when he married the soon-to-be-monarch on November 20, 1947.And in November last year, he celebrated 70 years of everlasting love with his wife, whom he shares four children, eight grandchildren and six great-grandchildren with.But his humorous gaffes and quips is perhaps what has helped keep Prince Philip &ldquosane with so many royal duties and more than 65 years of public service.The Queen&rsquos husband retired from public duties in August last year after completing 22,219 solo engagements since he was ascended to the throne in 1952.A look back at his life as a boy, young man and royal consort.                    Getty1 of 26Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh turned 94 on June 10th 2015, seen here in 1940 and 2014As his age has advanced beyond 90, concerns for Philip's well-being have increased as he has faced a number of health scares.Abdominal and hip surgery, bladder infections and a blocked coronary artery have seen the duke admitted to hospital on a number of occasions.And most recently, Philip went under the knife for a hip replacement operation, which saw him hospitalised for a few weeks back in April.But, recently the Duke was last pictured at his grandson Prince Harry&rsquos Royal Wedding to Meghan Markle where he looked in good spirits and walked unaided. Prince Philip vowed to be the Queen's 'ears and eyes' when the pair married   Prince Philip and the Queen's love story began in 1939 The love story of Philip and Elizabeth, who are distant cousins, began in 1939 when the young princess was just 13-years-old.The couple met during a royal visit to his naval college in Dartmouth. It was love at first sight and they started to write to each other.Dashing, blond-haired, athletic 18-year-old Philip is said to have caught her eye as he entertained her by jumping over tennis nets.Elizabeth was just 21 and Philip, who had renounced his Greek royal title and become a naturalised British subject, was 26 when the pair became engaged. Prince Philip has shared 70 years of blissful marriage with the Queen  Prince Philip retired in August last year It has been suggested that they became unofficially engaged in summer 1946 while they were staying at Balmoral.Prince Philip joined the Navy from school in 1939 aged 18 and went on to serve with distinction in the Mediterranean.He also saw battle in the Second World War and many royal insiders tipped him to go all the way in the senior service and become its chief or First Sea Lord.But the Duke resigned as a commander in 1951 when it became clear his father-in-law King George VI was in ill health.He was formally made a British prince in 1957 by his wife, after he became the Baron Greenwich, Earl of Merioneth and Duke of Edinburgh just before his wedding to the Queen.Indeed, the Prince had to wait until his 90th birthday in 2011 before becoming the titular head of the Royal Navy.And it was then that the Queen appointed him to the symbolic title of Lord High Admiral, which dates back to the 14th century, as thanks for his lifetime of dedication and in recognition of how he had sacrificed his naval career.But after the death of his father-in-law, the Duke threw himself into royal life to overcome the disappointment of the premature loss of his professional career.And after more than 65 years by the side of his wife Queen Elizabeth II, Prince Philip has certainly made his mark on the British monarchy as the moderniser of the firm.

title: Prince Philip birthday Duke of Edinburgh birthday pictures
story: The Queen&rsquos husband Prince Philip turns 97 today.Queen Elizabeth II&rsquos consort was born on June 10, 1921 in Greece. He was the Prince of Greece and Denmark before his engagement to Elizabeth, a princess at the time, in 1947.Following his retirement last year, Prince Philip has been seen on fewer official engagements then in previous years, however he has joined the Queen on numerous occasions.The Duke underwent hip replacement surgery earlier this year and has made a good recovery.Fortunately he was well enough to attend the Royal wedding of his grandson Prince Harry to Meghan Markle at Windsor Castle in May.The royal couple, who celebrated their platinum wedding anniversary in 2017, also welcomed their sixth great-grandchild Prince Louis in to the family this year.Look through this gallery to see pictures of the Duke of Edinburgh through the years.Pictures include Prince Philip as a young toddler in Greece to more recent photos at the wedding of Harry and Meghan last month.You will also see the Duke on his wedding day and with his young family at Balmoral in Scotland.GettyPrince Philip in pictures: Duke of Edinburgh celebrates 97th birthday

title: kate middleton princess charlotte pictures trooping the colour 2018
story: The three-year-old princess was consoled by her mother after a brief slip on the balcony of Buckingham Palace.Footage from the event shows the young royal may have hit her head on the railing as she fell, but after being picked up for a comforting hug by Kate, 36, she was back on her feet to enjoy the celebrations.Princess Charlotte was accompanied by her older brother, Prince George, and smiled and waved to well-wishers below as the crowds enjoyed the spectacle of one of the most impressive royal events of the year.The ceremony also included an RAF flypast, and the young prince, who turns five next month, could barely contain his excitement as the formation of warplanes roared overhead.EPAKate Middleton comforted Princess Charlotte after the young royal slipped during Trooping the ColourTrooping the Colour has been performed annually for more than 260 years in honour of the British monarch&rsquos birthday.This year&rsquos event marks the Queen&rsquos 92nd birthday, although Her Majesty&rsquos actual birthday is April 21.The parade officially begins after the Queen departs Buckingham Palace in a carriage to inspect the troops along a route across St James&rsquos Park towards Horse Guards Parade.More than 1,400 officers and men took part in the parade, as well as 400 musicians and 200 horses.                WATCH: Adorable Princess Charlotte taps along to national anthem                Moment Meghan curtsies to the Queen in Buckingham Palace balcony debutThis year&rsquos event took an unexpected turn when 79-year-old Field Marshall Lord Guthrie was thrown from his mount.Police rushed to the former Chief of the Defence Staff&rsquos aid while paramedics arrived on the scene.Lord Guthrie, who is Colonel of the Life Guards, is being &ldquowell looked after, according to aides.The fall briefly delayed the RAF flypast as the 79-year-old received medical attention.The parade marks the official birthday of the Sovereign, even though the Queen's actual birthday is on April 21st. title: princess eugenie royal wedding meghan markle prince harry royal family latest
story: The couple will get married in St George&rsquos Chapel at Windsor Castle, following in the footsteps of Meghan Markle and Prince Harry.In the UK alone, around 18 million viewers tuned in to watch the Duke and Duchess of Sussex get wed, with another 29.2 million watching from the US.But Royal expert Richard Fitzwilliams does not think Princess Eugenie, the ninth in line to the throne, and Jack Brooksbank&rsquos wedding will be anywhere near as popular.He told Expresss: &ldquoThe forthcoming wedding of Princess Eugenie to Jack Brooksbank on 12 October will garner more press attention than it normally would as with Harry and Meghan's wedding and Kate's baby it has been a unique royal year.Princess Eugenie of York and her fianc&eacute Jack Brooksbank will tie the knot on October 12                Princess Eugenie wedding: Fergie set for MAJOR role as big day looms                Princess Eugenie bags new job in run-up to wedding to Jack Brooksbank&ldquoThe Invictus Games this year are in Sydney from October 20-27 and Harry and Meghan are expected to go on a Commonwealth tour when they attend them which will get vast press as will any trip they take anywhere.&ldquoEugenie and Jack's wedding will be charming and picturesque but it is not an important royal event as she does not undertake royal duties.Mr Fitzwilliams concluded: &ldquoI just hope her mother the Duchess of York, a disaster when a member of the Royal Family and subsequently known for her erratic behaviour, keeps a low profile.&ldquoThe public won't be interested, why should they be?Princess Eugenie and Jack Brooksbank: A royal relationship in pictures as the couple prepare for their Royal wedding later this year. title: meat traces vegan vegetarian ready meals tesco sainsburys food standards agency
story: STOCKTESCOSAINSBURY'SA vegan product from Tesco and one from Sainsbury's have 'tested positive for traces of animal DNA' The Food Standards Agency (FSA) launched the probe today (Friday) after lab tests revealed traces of pork in Sainsbury&rsquos own brand &ldquomeat free meatballs and traces of turkey in a vegan macaroni meal from Tesco, The Daily  reports.In response to the &ldquoworrying findings, religious groups said some consumers would be &ldquodistressed to learn they had consumed products containing animal DNA.The Muslim Council of Britain called on the FSA to urgently recall any affected products.Both supermarkets say their own tests have not found any traces of meat.                Best weight loss diet finally revealed by scientists - is it low-carb?                Are Meghan Markle and Prince Harry vegan?Muslim Council of BritainThe Daily  said it had sent samples to a food testing laboratory accredited by the German Government after facilities in the UK reportedly refused to take on the job.The results revealed traces of pork DNA in Sainsbury&rsquos own brand Meat Free Meatballs 380g, according to the paper.Traces of turkey DNA in Tesco&rsquos Wicked Kitchen BBQ Butternut Mac 385g ready meal, which is labelled vegan, were also said to be found.The German lab claimed the presence of whole animal DNA picked up in the test indicated the products contained meat or animal skin. STOCKTesco said its own tests had not revealed any animal DNA in its productBut the lab said there was a small chance the DNA could have come from gelatine or oil, neither of which should be used in vegan dishes.The Muslim Council of Britain said: It is distressing for vegetarian and vegan consumers to learn that they may have consumed food products labelled as suitable for their use have been shown to contain animal DNA.We hope that the FSA will implement the recall procedure urgently and carry out a thorough investigation of what appears to be a contravention of the Trades Description Act.A spokesperson for Europe&rsquos largest Kosher agency, the Kosher London Beth Din, said: It is disappointing to hear that pork was found in a supposed vegetarian product and this news will understandably be worrying for people who do not wish to eat any type of meat. STOCKSainsbury's said its product was made in a meat-free factoryAn FSA spokeswoman confirmed an investigation was underway today (Friday), adding: &ldquoOur priority is to ensure consumers can be confident that the food they eat is safe and is what it says it is.A Sainsbury&rsquos spokeswoman said: &ldquoThese products are produced at a meat-free factory. Sainsbury&rsquos and the Vegetarian Society also carry out regular checks and no issues have been found. We are concerned by these findings, however, and are carrying out a comprehensive investigation alongside our supplier.A Tesco spokesman said: &ldquoWe take the quality and integrity of our products extremely seriously and understand that our vegan and vegetarian products should be exactly that.&ldquoOur initial DNA tests have found no traces of animal DNA in the BBQ Butternut Mac product available in stores today. We would urge the  to share full details of their testing, including the lab used as we continue to investigate.

title: bernese mountain dog help children read scotland literacy drive
story: FILESix-year-old Bernese Mountain Dog Oscar is preparing to front a children&rsquos literacy driveThe huge ball of fur who weighs in at 56kg &ndash close to 9st &ndash is expected to become a feature in South Lanarkshire&rsquos libraries to help youngsters become more confident readers.His owner, Gerry Campbell, works for the local authority and is promoting the initiative where dogs are used to tackle literacy problems among children.Pilot projects elsewhere in the UK have shown that pupils who are falling behind their peers can improve their skills by reading to dogs.The pets have proved to be an attentive audience with no fear of judgment, criticism or sniggering at those who are struggling to boost their confidence and reading ability.                Scottish campaign to shut down puppy farmers launched                Nazi salute-row bigot gets &pound100,000 for appealThese adorable dogs were born camera ready. Pup-arazzi photographer Lynn Terry has created a series of endearing moments in a unique new project - putting dogs into a photo-booth and capturing the way they mug it up for the camera1 of 21Gerry Campbell - Chief executive at South Lanarkshire Leisure and CultureMr Campbell, chief executive at South Lanarkshire Leisure and Culture, said they were in discussions to introduce Oscar to the organisation&rsquos 25 libraries.He added: &ldquoHe looks a bit like a bear and what child would not like to imagine he or she is reading to a bear?&ldquoOscar has the right personality for the role. He is a big, soft, well-behaved dog and would be well suited for it.&ldquoWe travel a lot as a family and he often comes with us. He&rsquos been to Michelin-starred restaurants and has never caused any trouble. He is a true gentleman. There are some issues with children in terms of numeracy and literacy skills and, although I don&rsquot know what he could do in terms of numeracy, Oscar can help to build their confidence and help them relax when they are reading. STOCKBernese Mountain Dogs are a versatile working breed and originate from the farmlands of SwitzerlandBernese Mountain Dogs are a versatile working breed and originate from the farmlands of Switzerland.Although large and sturdy, they are known for their friendly and calm disposition and, unlike huskies, do not need hours and hours of exercise.The father-of-two said: &ldquoWe&rsquove had Oscar from a pup and he&rsquos our second Bernese. He is a friendly chap and likes attention. It is not that common a breed, which is what attracted us to it.&nbsp&ldquoBut it took about 18 months of researching&nbsp to get to the point where we were ready to buy a pup and we were hugely impressed with the breeder in Preston who basically interviewed us to make sure we had the right kind of household for the dog.Two years ago, Oscar was also chosen as the cover dog for a Sawday&rsquos hotel guide to dog-friendly breaks in Britain.James Macdonald, of Canine Concern, said they already worked with around 65 schools and close to a 1,000 pupils but would welcome more volunteers. He added: &ldquoAnything that helps children to engage with reading and books is apositive thing. While it does not work for every child, the fact you have a non-judgmental audience is definitely a positive experience and can boost not only confidence but also the actual reading.&ldquoIf Mr Campbell wants to find out more about how we can work together, we&rsquod be delighted to hear from him. We are always looking for more volunteers.

title: grimsby earthquake 2018 lincolnshire yorkshire british geoligical survey
story: EMSCGrimsby has been hit by a 3.9 magnitude earthquakeThe British Geological Survey said the seismic event took place at 11.14pm last nightwith its epicentre in Grimsby and at a depth of 11 miles.Residents in north east Lincolnshire, north Lincolnshire and Hull&nbsp felt the earthquake.People reported feeling their houses shake suddenly in a small, violent tremor lasting a few seconds.                UK earthquake: Expert says earthquake is the 'largest in 10 years'                UK struck by 21 earthquakes in 50 days amid the biggest for 10 yearsThe impact was felt in Scunthorpe and across the Humber in Hull and as far as West and East Yorkshire.One resident said: &ldquoI felt the whole house shake for a second. I jumped up because I didn't know what it was. We ran around the house checking to see what had happened. It was like something had fallen off the roof.Local councillor Stewart Rawlings said in Huntington it was like a violent washing machine spin cycle.Another said: &ldquoJust heard England had earthquake! 3.9! That is on the ho-hum scale in California.&ldquoBut their buildings aren&rsquot built to take it.&ldquoIn CA that kind of quake could be a &ldquoforeshock before BIG one.And another added: &ldquoOut of everywhere in England, love how Hull got a bloody mini-earthquake.The tremor hit nearly a decade after a 5.2-magnitude earthquake at Market Rasen in Lincolnshire, which was felt widely across England and Wales.The largest earthquake this year took place in Cwmllynfell in south Wales on February 17 and registered a magnitude of 4.6.BGSBGS graphic showing the epicentre of the Grimsby earthquakeThe BGS said it had received reports including how the whole house shook for a couple of seconds, heard a rumble with a simultaneous trembling, the bed started to shake, the radiator jolted and someone who thought it was a lorry crashing outside.It said such earthquakes were not uncommon in the UK and happened about every two years.Independent organisation European-Mediterranean Seismological Centre (EMSC) said it had received reports from people more than 60 moles from the epicentre who had felt the tremor.

title: Elgin Marbles British Museum Jeremy Corbyn
story: The sculptures have been housed in the British Museum since 1816Hartwig Fischer insisted the museum provided a &ldquounique setting for the sculptures after the Labour leader told a Left-wing Greek newspaper they should be returned to the Parthenon.Mr Fischer, who took over as director in 2016, said: &ldquoThe Parthenon sculptures are a vital part of this world collection that seeks to tell the history of humanity over two million years.&ldquoThere are very few places in the world that can do that.&ldquoI think it&rsquos beneficial that some of the sculptures that remain are here in London where they tell this world story and some are in Athens where they can tell the story of the importance of classical Greece.                EU admits the Elgin Marbles will REMAIN in Britain after Brexit                Jeremy Corbyn VOWS to return ELGIN MARBLES if he becomes PM&ldquoThe museum is always seeking to extend our knowledge of these objects. For example, we have an exhibition on at the moment which looks at the profound effect they had on the French sculptor Rodin.&ldquoThis provides a great example of how the museum provides a unique setting for the sculptures.Mr Fischer&rsquos predecessor Neil McGregor said in 2014 there was &ldquono possibility of putting the Elgin Marbles back during his tenure. Last week Mr Corbyn told Ta Nea newspaper: &ldquoThe Parthenon sculptures belong to Greece.The sculptures have been housed in the British Museum since 1816 after they were bought by the Government from Lord Elgin.He removed them from Athens between 1799 and 1810 after obtaining permission from Ottoman officials who ruled Greece at the time.

title: brexit news rarron banks russia meetings russian ambassador leave eu campaign
story: Mr Banks said he didn't profit from any business deals because he didn't pursue anything.Mr Banks was introduced to the ambassador Alexander Yakovenko by a suspected Russian intelligence officer, according to The Sunday Times.The paper said it had seen emails by Mr Banks and Leave.EU communications chief Andy Wigmore showing they had repeated contacts with Russian officials to discuss matters of mutual interest throughout the EU referendum campaign and its aftermath.The reports are likely to raise fresh questions about whether the Kremlin sought to influence the outcome of the 2016 vote.                Brexiteer MP says THIS will help Britain play HARDBALL in talks                EU unravels as THESE five countries fight Brussels power grab                Gordon Brown thinks he knows WHY Brits voted for BrexitAsked about the report at the G7 summit in Quebec, Theresa May said: I am sure that if there are any allegations that need investigation the proper authorities will do that.Hitting back on Twitter, Mr Banks said he will &ldquoexplain the Russian &amp Brexit witch hunt &amp reveal some other very interesting information in an interview with the BBC on Monday.&nbspMr Banks, who last week announced he was pulling out of the Commons inquiry into fake news, accusing the MPs of a witch hunt, said he would now be giving evidence to the Digital, Culture, Media and Sport Committee as planned on Tuesday.According to The Sunday Times, the emails showed Mr Banks met Mr Yakovenko on three occasions - having previously only acknowledged one encounter in 2015 - and made a visit to Moscow in February 2016 in the midst of the referendum campaign.The Prime Minister of England, Theresa May, speaking at the G7 summit in Quebec. The paper said that he and Mr Wigmore had also had lunch with the ambassdor in November 2016 - just three days after they and Nigel Farage had met Donald Trump in New York following his victory in the US presidential election.They were said to have been introduced to Mr Yakovenko by Alexander Udod - one of 23 suspected Russian intelligence officers subsequently ejected from the UK after the poisoning of Sergei and Yulia Skripal in Salisbury.The ambassador was said to have proposed a business deal that would have involved them in the consolidation into one company of six Russian goldmines.The emails were passed to paper by journalist Isabel Oakeshott, Banks's ghostwriter on The Bad Boys of Brexit, who is now writing a book with the Tory peer Lord Ashcroft on Russia's use of hybrid warfare to influence British politics.Theresa May sought to unite EU leaders in condemnation of Moscow over the poisoning of a former Russian spy, but she faces resistance from states keen to protect their Kremlin ties                    REUTERS1 of 17Jean-Claude Juncker and Britain's Prime Minister Theresa MayThe paper said she came forward after she said her email accounts were hacked.Ms Oakeshott said: Banks and Wigmore were shamelessly used by the Russians.Perhaps, the Englishmen did not mind. Banks and Wigmore genuinely sympathised - and continue to sympathise - with some of Putin's political views.Mr Banks dismissed the claims, telling the paper: I had two boozy lunches with the Russian ambassador and another cup of tea with him. Bite me. It's a convenient political witchhunt, both over Brexit and Trump.He said nothing had come of their discussions over the goldmine deal, adding: &ldquoWe didn't profit from any business deals because I never pursued anything.Theresa May has said that if any allegations need investigating then the authorities will do so. Mr Banks, whose wife is Russian, acknowledged that he had made a family trip to Moscow in February 2016, but said no meetings were had with anyone.He said he also disclosed details of his contacts with the Russians to US officials.Mr Banks said: We actually saw the suits from the American embassy who introduced us to the State Department to explain what had happened and then we briefed the Americans on our meetings with the Russians.&nbspMr Wigmore told the paper: We never offered any information to him (Mr Yakovenko) or any Russian any details of our (Brexit) campaign.There was no immediate response from Leave.EU.

story: Stroud&rsquos David Drew said he regretted the commentThe shadow minister said sorry less than 24 hours after the analogy, following complaints.He said: &ldquoI am passionate about animal welfare but this comparison was inappropriate and I apologise.He earlier told a Commons debate on the fur trade: &ldquoI do not understand not only why we cannot lean on the retail trade, but why people wear fur.&ldquoTo me it is the same as wearing a swastika.Jewish businessmen and women condemned the Nazi comparison. Frank Zilberkweit, who owns Polar Furs, said: &ldquoMr Drew will be aware as shadow minister for environment, food and rural affairs, that the UK fur trade is dominated by businesses run by Jewish families.                Springwatch Chris Packham pressures MPs as they debate banning fur                Britain will NOT ban fur say MPs&ldquoIt was grossly insensitive and anti-Semitic to try to attack our legitimate industry by comparing it to the sale of swastikas.&ldquoFor my family and many others in the fur trade, the swastika is an emblem of extermination and heartache.Mr Zilberkweit, 69, has led the firm for 50 years. His father and uncle fled Germany in the 1930s to escape the Nazis but many friends were sent to death camps.International Fur Federation&rsquos Mark Oaten also attacked Mr Drew, saying: &ldquoHow can he say that people buying fur items is like wearing a swastika?&ldquoGiven the attitude of his party to the Jewish community I guess it&rsquos not a surprise.

title: thousands of brits set to get more cash as they move on to universal credit after rules change
story: Ministers have admitted that too many people are losing money when they switch to the new benefits regime.So they have softened the rules - meaning claimants will get more support to ensure they dont lose out.Those affected by the rule tweak will include working parents, the disabled and jobseekers who find work but lose it again.Its likely to mean thousands of Brits getting hundreds more pounds a year in benefits.And many more who lost out will get money back too.The Government has introduced a scheme called transitional protection which ensures that claimants who are moved to Universal Credit dont see a reduction in their overall level of handouts if their circumstances are unchanged.If their UC entitlement is less than they previously got, they are eligible for a cash top-up.Today Work and Pensions Secretary Esther McVey announced transitional protection would be extended more widely.Seriously disabled adults who live alone but rely on care, currently getting Severe Disability Premium, will now be guaranteed extra money when they start on UC.Parents who are in work will also get transitional protection which ensures they wont be stung if their cost of childcare goes up.And anyone who sees their earnings increase, for example because they start a new job, only for their pay to fall again shortly afterwards will see their benefits ring-fenced.Campaigners said that some families were £147 worse off per month.At least 4,000 people are set to benefit from the backpayments because they lost out when the moved from severe disabilities benefits onto Universal Credit. And more people who lost out when they moved into temporary work will also receive a boost.Ms McVey said: This Government is committed to delivering a welfare system that supports claimants and is fair to taxpayers.Universal Credit is currently being rolled out across the country but has been hit by a string of delays and blunders.

title: brexit sell out david davis sun says
story: The Government intends to offer the EU a “backstop” arrangement that could shackle us to its restrictive ­customs rules for ever to resolve the over-hyped Irish border issue.Brexit Secretary David Davis managed to get an end-date inserted, December 2021, but it was fudged as a mere “expectation”. It is not legally binding.It is supposedly temporary. But that is naïve. It gives the EU no incentive to negotiate the free trade deal we want.They will have us where they want us. They can reject Irish solutions for ever.We would be stuck,  unwillingly locked into their customs rules — but now with no say over them.No meaningful external trade deals. No full independence. Brexit’s key  economic argument destroyed. Without having prepared the country to walk away with “no deal”, what could we do?No wonder Remainers are cock-a-hoop.Is there embarrassment in No10? Or fear? No. Just GLEE, that Theresa May had stitched up Davis with the wooliness of the wording. “She’s done him like a kipper again,” said one source.It’s not the Brexit Secretary done up like a kipper. It’s Brexit and 17.4million voters. Mrs May must stand up for them. All we see is capitulation.AMAZON is creating 2,500 jobs. Fantastic — except House of Fraser is cutting 6,000. And 5,300 could go at Poundworld.Look no further for an illustration of the carnage on our high streets and the main reason why.Our stores simply cannot cope  with the cheap online competition alongside the sky-high business rates  on their premises.Before long our towns may only house restaurants, coffee shops, nail bars, barbers and tattooists. To retain a vibrant mix, stores need a level playing field.Which means far lower taxes for them. And Amazon paying every penny they owe.THE Tories need to stop swallowing the line that taxes must rise to fund the NHS.The sole reason the public seems prepared to pay more, as a poll indicates, is that both the Tories and Labour have convinced them it’s the only solution.It isn’t. Tax hikes should be a last resort. Government waste is still vast. So is the insane aid budget. Cut those first.The Tories cannot win votes posing as a saner version of Corbyn’s Labour. They should be unshakeable defenders of low taxes to boost the economy.Raising the overall burden beyond its  30-year high is political suicide, no matter the cause.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: queens brithday honours 2018 kenny dalglish knighted
story: Dalglish and his wife Marina have raised millions of pounds for cancer treatment and has also been a tireless campaigner for justice for the families of the 96 killed in the Hillsborough disaster.The 67-year-old Glaswegian was manager of Liverpool at the time of the tragedy - and is one of just two British managers to win the Premier League as boss of Blackburn in 1995.Last night he said he was “hugely proud to have accepted the accolade” - in recognition for services to football, charity and the City of Liverpool.And he joked that he thought the letter informing him of the knighthood had been from the taxman.Sir Kenny said: “We only set out to do the best we possibly could, even through all the other stuff - the charity or Hillsborough, it was to help people because somebody helped us.”Defoe dedicated his OBE to brave cancer tot Bradley Lowery, who he became friends with in the final months of his tragically short life.The Bournemouth striker said he was “truly honoured and humbled” to receive the award - given in recognition for his charitable work through the Jermain Defoe Foundation, which was set up to raise money for underprivileged children in the Caribbean and the UK.Defoe said he felt “mixed emotions” over the award, coming nearly a year after Bradley’s death aged 6.He said he wanted to “scream with joy” when his mum rang him up while he was on holiday to tell him about the OBE.But the footballer - speaking alongside his mother, added: “There’s been a lot of tears, it’s been tough. There have been times I’ve been in my car and I’ve - no one knows but you’re crying on your own.”Dedicating the award to Bradley, Defoe said: “I woke up this morning and I did think about Bradley. It was a special relationship.“There were times when I stood there and I thought ‘I don’t understand, what have I really done?’ Bradley is the one who’s suffered.”OBEs were handed to world heavyweight champion boxer Anthony Joshua and Britain’s most successful Winter Olympic athlete Lizzie Yarnold, who defended her skeleton title at the PyeongChang games earlier this year.The youngest award winner on the list is 20-year-old alpine skier Menna Fitzpatrick, Britain’s most successful winter paralympian, picking up an MBE - while her sighted guide Jennifer Kehoe was also rewarded.Former Welsh rugby player Dai Morris was given an MBE and 1988 Olympic gold medal winning hockey player Richard Leman was handed an OBE.Renowned opera singer Dame Kiri Te Kanawa was given the distinguished title of Companion of Honour.TV presenter Bamber Gascoigne, best known for being the original quizmaster on University Challenge, gets a CBE.Actress Fenella Fielding, 90, was awarded with an OBE. She was popular in the 1950s and 1960s and known as Englands first lady of the double entendre.Archers star Timothy Bentinck said he was astonished and humbled to be made an MBE.In the business sphere, Judy Naake, who made millions selling St Tropez self-tanning products - initially from the back of her car - receives an MBE for services to entrepreneurship, the community and philanthropy.Jo Malone, creator of the self-titled luxury perfumery brand who has since started the fragrance-centred Jo Loves business, is awarded a CBE for services to the British economy and the GREAT Britain campaign, which encourages people to visit and invest in the UK.Best-selling novelist Ken Follett said he was proud to be made a CBE for doing something I love.The spy thriller and historical fiction writer, 69, is made a CBE in the Queens Birthday Honours for services to literature and charity.Folletts novels include The Pillars Of The Earth, Eye Of The Needle, The Man From St Petersburg and Fall Of Giants.Tim Waterstone, founder of the high street bookstore, was given a knighthood.Veteran war journalist Kate Adie was handed a CBE.CHIEF Remain luvvie Emma Thompson was made a Dame in the Queen’s Birthday Honours list last night as a string of Europhiles were rewarded.The Remains of the Day actress sparked outrage during the EU referendum campaign by branding Britain “a cake-filled misery-laden grey old island”.Jacob Rees-Mogg MP said: “I hope it lifts a little of her misery when she contemplates the country she thinks is grey and, for some reason, cake-filled.”Other Brexit opponents honoured include historian Mary Beard, who was made a Dame, and novelist Kazuo Ishiguro who became a knight.ACTRESS Keira Knightley was handed an OBE last night — 15 years after scoring her breakthrough role.The star, who struck fame in 2002’s Bend It Like Beckham and moved on to hits like Love Actually, was ­honoured for services to drama and charity.She became the face of an Amnesty International hu­man rights campaign and has worked with Oxfam, Women’s Aid, WaterAid and Unicef.Keira, 33, nominated for Oscars for Pride &amp Prejudice and The Imitation Game, was joined on the honours list by Tom Hardy.The actor, 40, received a CBE for services to drama.Veteran war journalist Kate Adie also got a CBE.RAPPER Ms Dynamite was recognised with an MBE for services to music in the Queen’s Birthday Honours List.The Mercury Prize-winning artist, born Niomi Arleen McLean-Daley, 37, burst onto the scene with earworm hit Dy-na-mi-tee, which featured on her debut album A Little Deeper.Her album won critical acclaim in the UK and US, and saw her win Brit Awards for Best British Urban Act and Best British Female Solo Artist in 2003.She returned to music in 2005 after the birth of her son with her second, politically-informed album Judgement Days featuring a plea to Tony Blair on the track called Mr Prime Minister.After winding down her music career, she has featured on television and in recent years appeared on Katy B’s Lights On track, as well as Magnetic Man’s Fire.In 2016, she was honoured with a Paving the Way MOBO award for her contribution to music as a female MC.THE honours system was dubbed “rewards for failure” last night after Network Rail boss Mark Carne got a gong despite the chaos on the railways.The £820,000-a-year chief exec, quitting this year, was given a CBE for his part in “modernisation of the rail infrastructure”.Even Network Rail chairman Sir Peter Hendy said the timing is “difficult” after the timetables failure of the last few weeks.Labour MP John Mann said: “This is one of the most extraordinary rewards for failure. Something is very wrong with the way we are currently running the country.”Fellow Labour MP Wes Streeting said it would “go down like a cup of sick” with commuters.Other gongs for failure include Canadian-born Royal Mail boss Moya Greene, who becomes a Dame despite overseeing its disastrous privatisation and a plunge in revenues.A Home Office immigration officer got an MBE despite the Windrush scandal and the 100,000 net immigration target being repeatedly missed.DWP official Karen Gosden got an OBE despite delays and errors with the rollout of the Government’s Universal Credit welfare reform scheme.And health quango Nice’s boss David Haslam was knighted despite refusing terminally ill NHS patients key drugs.BRITAIN’S longest-serving poppy seller is “over the moon” after being awarded an MBE.Rosemary Powell, 103, plans to hang up her collection box later this year after a remarkable 97 years collecting for the appeal as she is “getting old”.She first helped her mum Evelyn sell poppies aged six for the Royal British Legion’s first appeal in 1921.She lost two godfathers and three uncles during the First World War.Londoner Rosemary said last night: “It is very nice that I have been given this. I still vividly remember selling poppies on Richmond Bridge with my mother.”Her son Giles said: “The MBE is a tremendous reward for years of hard work and loyalty. Mum is absolutely over the moon. It’s great recognition for a lot of hard work.”During World War Two, Mrs Powell - now a great-grandmother — trained as a voluntary aid detachment nurse providing civilian nursing to the military.Her younger brother Peter a major in the Army, died in the conflict.She lived in Africa for a year in the 1950s and made poppies out of paper to give to locals during Remembrance.The brother of aid worker David Haines, who was beheaded by IS extremists, was also honoured.Mike Haines, 51, was awarded an OBE for his work in striving to reject terrorism. He set up the Global Acts of Unity project, which promotes peace and tolerance in schools across the country.He dedicated the honour to David, 44, murdered in 2014 after being taken hostage in Syria while working for a relief agency.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: dont hide your demons behind a smile like kate spade or anthony bourdain ask for help
story: Frances Beatrix, known as Bea, is just 13 and having to come to terms with the fact that her mum Kate Spade took her own life.Then there is 11-year-old Ariane Bourdain, whose father, travel and food writer Anthony Bourdain, was found dead in his Paris hotel room yesterday in an apparent suicide.Kate Spade reportedly left a note for her daughter which read: “Bea, I have always loved you. This is not your fault. Ask Daddy!”Can you imagine how that little girl must be feeling?She’s lost her mother and some have surmised the note appears to point the finger at her dad.It’s obviously not at all clear if that was really Kate’s intention, or whether she just wanted her daughter to seek answers and comfort from her father.That’s the trouble with suicide. Those left behind have to deal with so many unanswered questions.Look at little Ariane, who has just lost her beloved dad and will also be left with feelings of confusion and anger, as well as searing grief.Anthony, 61, was an award-winning chef and TV presenter.He was in France filming an episode of his successful CNN series, Parts Unknown, when he was found unresponsive in his hotel room.He was a larger-than-life, passionate character who championed the underdog and supported his girlfriend Asia Argento, one of the first actresses to accuse Harvey Weinstein of rape.Both Kate and Anthony were successful and, as far as the rest of the world was concerned, were living the dream.But no one really knows what goes on behind closed doors.Kate, who was 55, met husband Andy 35 years ago.They were married for 24 years but had been living apart for the past ten months, while sharing parental duties.They hadn’t discussed divorce and Andy said they still loved each other very much.He went on to say there was no indication that Kate was going to kill herself and his priority now is to protect and comfort his daughter.He will not only be grieving but inevitably feel he should have been able to somehow prevent this tragedy.People have asked “Who in their right mind would leave their own child to grow up motherless?”, but that’s the point.Kate wasn’t “in her right mind” and it seems neither was Anthony.People who kill themselves are suffering mental distress that no one can understand unless they have walked a mile in their shoes.On the surface, Kate had it all. Many thought she was still happily married. The couple had a healthy daughter, her designer label was a massive success.Kate was also good looking, funny and always seemed happy in interviews and photos. But now we know the poor woman was in agony.According to members of her family she had suffered from mental health problems for many years, and there has been speculation she was reluctant to seek help.If this was the case, then the reasons put forward for Kate trying to cope on her own are heartbreaking.She was apparently worried that her business, based on her cheerful handbags, would be affected if it was known she suffered from anxiety and depression. That really is desperately sad.Not only was Kate trying to cope with her demons but her marriage was going through a rocky patch and all the while she felt as though she had to paint on a smile and pretend everything was fine.Her life became so unbearable that she believed her only escape was to end it all.Her husband has said she was undergoing treatment and taking medication, yet Kate’s death shows that despite a change in attitudes towards those unfortunate enough to suffer from mental health problems, there is still a very long way to go.There are still people who will tell sufferers who are clearly very unwell to man up, or pull themselves together, which is just about the worst thing you could do.Suicide is a growing problem and each death is a tragedy. It is the biggest killer of men aged 20 to 49 in the UK. At least 84 men will have taken their own lives this week.If so many people were being lost to a virus there would be a national outcry and funds would be made available to find the cause and cure.Mental illness is still a Cinderella disease, and that cannot continue.But there are glimmers of hope.On TV we’ve seen the effect of Aidan Connor’s suicide on his friends and family in Coronation Street. It was tough to watch but raised awareness on a massive scale.We have seen raw grief but also deep anger and Aidan was branded selfish by his distraught sister.Those closest to him have experienced guilt because they didn’t realise how much pain he was in and have suffered sleepless nights and have been torturing themselves for not knowing how bad it was and for not offering help.Corrie shone a light in a dark place and I believe this storyline and the tragedy of Kate Spade and the apparent suicide of Anthony Bourdain will make people think.None of us knows what private battles are being fought against the dark demons of mental illness, even among our family and close friends.We all need to be watchful and unafraid to ask if everything really is OK. We need to be prepared to be rebuffed but to gently persist if we feel there is a real problem.The black despair that it seems Anthony Bourdain and Kate Spade succumbed to could happen to any one of us.If you feel depressed, please, I beg you, be brave and ask for help. And let’s all be prepared to reach out to that person in despair.I FIND it utterly ludicrous that in the eyes of the law a criminal who steals your pet is treated in exactly the same way as if they stole your TV or sofa.There’s no consideration for the fact that your dog or cat is a living, breathing animal and a much beloved member of the family.If the thieves are caught, although unlikely in these days of police cuts, the monetary value of the pet is the only consideration when it comes to sentencing.This is bonkers. You simply cannot put a price on your pet.So I am delighted that a campaign to change the law is gaining momentum.What all concerned dog and cat lovers want is higher sentencing for the theft of our animals and to reclassify stealing a pet as a crime in its own right.Hopefully this would act as a deterrent to pet theft, something alarmingly on the increase.One of those who passionately wants the law to change is Sir Bruce Forsyth’s daughter Debbie Matthews.Back in 2006, both her dogs were stolen from her car.She appeared on GMTV with her dad to make a heartfelt plea begging for the return of Yorkshire terriers Gizmo and Widget.Thankfully, within hours of appearing on the show, people who had bought the dogs in good faith at a market realised they were stolen from Debbie and she was emotionally reunited with them.It was a traumatic time for the whole family and Debbie knows she was incredibly lucky her story had a happy ending.So many owners never see their pets again and are left with endless worries about their fate.If you want to help change the law, do sign the pet theft petition at petition.parliament.uk/petitions/212174 and make your voice heard.IT was impossible to take the p*** out of Peter Stringfellow, because he would be first to make fun of himself.He knew his habit of wearing tiny thongs made him look daft, and was well aware that his mullet haircut was old-fashioned and silly and that people considered him to be a bit naff.When he was pilloried, he just gave one of his big guffaws and carried on enjoying himself.Peter was funny, kind-hearted and generous to a fault.He bore his illness with great stoicism and bravery and will be sadly missed.POLDARK returns to our screens tomorrow night amid a row over what many in Scotland refer to as “taps aff”.This occurs on those wonderful, albeit rare, occasions when the sunshine beams warmly north of the border and allows chaps to remove their cagoules, sweatshirts, woolly jumpers and tops.Aidan Turner, who plays Captain Poldark, is probably one of the most famous exponents of “taps aff” in recent times, ever since those sweaty scything scenes in his first series.It turns out that it was Aidan’s idea to take off his cambric shirt and scythe away in those tight breeches.But it’s caused the mother of all rows, with admiring women being accused of “objectifying” the bold captain.I have thoughtfully reproduced an image of a topless Aidan so you can make up your own minds.You will either think this photograph adds to the joy of a Saturday or be horrified by the sexualisation of the poor, unfortunate man.Frankly, I’m happy to wallow in this fantastic view and look forward to tomorrow, BBC1, 9pm, when I can enjoy some cracking writing, proper acting and top production values.Those “taps aff” scenes only enhance the pleasure of Poldark and, don’t forget, no one forced Aidan to show his pert nipples.He knows full well he’s a handsome fella and it was all his choice, for which we are truly grateful.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: theresa may love island hayley hughes brexit
story: The PM came clean about her failure to understand the reality show craze sweeping Britain as she flew to the G7 summit in Canada.Mrs May was quizzed on her views on how more than twice the number of people applied to go on the ITV2 programme this year as tried to get into Oxbridge.The PM admitted: “I have a confession to make to you, I have never seen Love Island.“I’m probably not best placed to comment on the interests people have in Love Island.”Asked by The Sun if she would like a description of what happens on the sex-filled show to help her, the PM joked: “With actions?”In what served as a tit for tat response, one Love Island contestant has revealed that she knows nothing of Mrs May’s biggest political mission while in No10.When asked about Brexit, blonde model Hayley Hughes stunned viewers on Friday night by responding: “What’s that? I seriously don’t have a clue”.Once it was explained that Brexit meant Britain leaving the EU, the 21 year-old from Liverpool then went on to inexplicably ask: “Does that mean we won’t have any trees?”Downing Street aides revealed the PM’s two favourite TV programmes are Homeland and the 10 O’Clock News.Mrs May and husband Philip are currently captivated by the most recent season of the US drama about ex-CIA agent Carrie Mathison.Mirroring modern day reality, Carrie tries to save the US from chaos sewn by Russian fake news attacks.GOT a story? title: german sas troops storm embassy dresden
story: The armed, camouflage-clad soldiers rappelled onto the roof of the Military Museum from a helicopter hovering 20m above the building.Masked members of the Kommando Spezialkräfte (KSK) then expertly abseiled down to a narrow ledge and got into position.Incredible images showed the window and its frame exploding into tiny fragments, allowing the troops easy entry for the faux extraction.They left the building with the hostage safely in tow, according to the Stuttgarter, but the danger wasnt over just yet.The soldiers, highly trained in both counter-terrorism and hostage rescue, came under mock fire as they tried to take the hostage to safety.A big screen outside the museum beamed footage of the daring rescue to hundreds of locals and tourists gathered out front.They cheered and applauded when Brigadier General Alexander Sollfrank, commander of the KSK, signalled the operation was over.He said the point of the exercise was to show the public they had the best personnel, excellent equipment and the necessary training to carry out such tasks.Sollfrank added: The essential message is: Should they find themselves in crisis, there are forces in the Federal Republic of Germany that are ready to get them out.The action-backed exercise summoned memories of the Iranian Embassy Siege on April 30, 1980, when six men forced their way into the building on Princes Gate.In a rescue mission dubbed Operation Nimrod, an SAS team entered through the roof and dropped an explosive through the skylight to cover their entrance and cause confusion among the terrorists.Iconic news footage and pictures showed the troops abseiling through the windows of the embassy, rescuing 19 hostages and killing five terrorists.

title: muslim campaigner celebrates british muslims
story: Despite the killings, the country has remained resolutely united.Today, The Sun on Sunday and The Sun proudly begin a series of articles from inspirational British Muslims who are leading figures in our hospitals, the legal profession and sport.Campaigner Fiyaz Mughal founded Tell MAMA, a group supporting victims of anti-Muslim hate and allowing them to report their concerns, in 2012.Fiyaz, a social entrepreneur and also director of interfaith group Faith Matters, writes here as we proudly celebrate the British Muslims, who help make our nation great.IN 2017 Britain suffered an appalling spate of terrorist atrocities, culminating in a shocking anti-Muslim attack on Finsbury Park mosque almost exactly a year ago.The roots of this hatred go back a long way. I believe the horrifying murder of soldier Lee Rigby in May 2013 was a turning point.As the founder of Tell MAMA, I found myself in the unenviable position of having to mobilise my tiny team at the time to help the growing number of people being targeted at a street and online level by anti-Muslim hatred.The backlash was significant, given the targeting of a young soldier minding his own business and the brutal manner of the terrorist attack.In the aftermath, Ukrainian neo-Nazi Pavlo Lapshyn placed three bombs in mosques in Wolverhampton, Walsall and Tipton — two months after murdering Mohammed Saleem, a grandfather walking back home from his mosque in Birmingham.The past five years have seen no let-up in the UK.People acting alone and small insular cells of men, and increasingly women, have carried out attacks at London Bridge, in Manchester, Finsbury Park and Westminster Bridge.And let us not ­forget the multiple terrorist attacks on 7/7 and the attempted attacks on civilians on 21/7.Our country has had its fair share of local and national triggers for potential tensions, but the unique nature of British society has meant we have not seen riots on our streets, such as those in Oldham in 2001 — and this is something to be ­celebrated.Terrorist trigger points have clearly led to rises in anti-Muslim hate incidents and there have been points where our country has been under ­significant pressure.After 7/7 and the significant loss of life that took place then, Britain was on a heightened state of alert as another plot failed to deliver its deadly cargo and the police and security services were in a race to find members of that terror cell.Dubbed 21/7, the country was shaken, ­communities were fearful and there was a crackle in the air as some people aired their frustrations openly.Even after all of this, we as communities held together.There is therefore something unique in our country which means community violence has not broken out, whereas in other European ­countries there have been street clashes and the widespread intimidation of minority communities.That “uniqueness” in our country is based on the old tradition that is ingrained in our society — that of “live and let live”, and “fair play”.It also underscores that the space for the accommodation of ideas and new populations has been a fundamental and historic part of our country though today, with resource pressures, there are limits.However, this is not only one-way traffic, and a sense of pride and identity within groups such as Britain’s Muslims has shown itself time and time again.It is therefore important to note that while ­younger citizens are less proud to be English, poll after poll has shown that Muslims living here are more ­patriotic than the average Brit.This means many Muslims do feel pride in a country where they can worship freely, be who they want to be and have the ability to practice their faith how they want to.We also have to say what is patently obvious, that Muslims have more freedoms in the United Kingdom compared to their counterparts in ­mainland Europe, where veil bans, harassment and chronic unemployment blight Muslim and other minority communities.It is this freedom to worship without fear, allied to the British sense of fair play, that makes us a place many countries look up to.The fact is our futures are inter-related and will continue to be as people travel more and ­connect through social media.It also means many of our preconceptions of different communities will change over time.This can be a force for good, though hand-in-hand with this must be that there are a unique set of values in our country.They have held us together in the darkest moments and have strengthened our resolve to stand together. Of this, we can always be proud.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: schoolkids should be taught how to swear to help them grasp language better experts claim
story: Banning children from using four-letter words will only make them curse more in the long run, an expert says.Neuroscientist Emma Byrne said: “Swearing is part of children’s social development.Learning how to use swearing effectively is far better than trying to ban children using it.“Talking honestly about why people swear helps to demystify the words and also the emotions of the people around them.”Emma, author of Swearing is Good For You, said it was bad to tell kids not to curse if they hear you doing it.She told a science festival in Cheltenham, Gloucs: “If they hear you swear in traffic and you say, ‘I never ever . . . don’t use that language’, they are going to go, ‘mum’s a massive sh**ting hypocrite’.”Earlier studies have shown swearing relieves pain.Researcher Richard Stephens, at Keele University, Staffs, found that volunteers could keep their hand in icy water longer when they were swearing than when shouting a neutral word.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: tory brexiteers plot coup pm
story: Despairing Brexiteers are considering a coup as they take part in crunch EU departure votes this week.THE Bill will likely go back to the House of Lords on June 18 under the so-called “ping-pong” process.Some Peers could try to send back similar “meaningful vote” and Customs Union amendments. It is likely to be met with some opposition to stave off a constitutional crisis.They are prepared to force a no-confidence vote in the PM which would lead to a leadership contest once the legislation is secured.Tory MPs are furious at her handling of the Brexit talks and fear the UK will be stuck with EU customs rules at the next election.But they would only act once the EU Withdrawal Bill becomes law, which is likely to be in the coming weeks.One said: “The short-term focus is getting Royal Assent for the Bill before we break for summer.The other flashpoint could be over Ministers being required to show Parliament by the autumn that it has tried to negotiate a Customs Union.If we steer it on to the statute book I wouldn’t be surprised if there’s a vote of no confidence in the PM, something I’d have said ‘no chance’ to a month ago.”Another said Mrs May had frustrated Tories over the backstop option that would kick in if a new customs arrangement was not in place by the end of 2020.Brexit Secretary David Davis threatened to quit if the December 2021 end date was not in the offer to Brussels.The senior Tory MP said: “In the past people thought she would see Brexit through. That’s why people stuck by her after the General Election. Now she is wobbling.”It would have meant less than an hour’s debate for each amendment. But this has changed to two six-hour sittings on Tuesday and Wednesday.Despite Tory infighting, the party has a seven-point lead over Labour. The opposition commanded an 11-point lead at Christmas. A Downing Street source said last night “For all the noises off, the fundamentals don’t change.“The PM is committed to delivering a good deal on Brexit, to leaving the Single Market and Customs Union.We’ll take back control of our money, laws and borders.”A DOZEN Tory rebels are understood to be considering their options before deciding on how to vote on the key amendments.The pro-EU group include former Chancellor Ken Clarke, ex-Education Secretary Nicky Morgan and ex-Defence Minister Anna Soubry.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: teacher 26 miss sprinkles cherokee county school
story: Cops in North Carolina, US, were called in by the 26-year-olds school when the reported relationship emerged.She is charged with engaging in sex acts with a student while employed by the Cherokee County Schools System.The Cherokee County Sheriffs Office told the channel that they began an investigation when alerted to a possible illegal sexual relationship between an educator and student.They received a report that 26-year-old Kayla Sprinkles had apparently been sexually involved with a student.On Monday, investigators presented their findings to the grand jury.They jury then made the decision to indict Sprinkles on five counts of sexual activity with a student.The sheriff’s office told the channel that Sprinkles apparently learned about the indictments, and turned herself in to the Mecklenburg County Detention Center.Sprinkles was served the indictments, and released on £19,000 ($25,000) unsecure bond.She taught and coached softball and cross country at Andrews High School in the 2016-17 school year.Sheriff Derrick Palmer told WDEF: “Our youth and our students are one of the greatest resources that Cherokee County is blessed to have.It is incumbent upon all of us to ensure their safety and well being as they grow and mature.”Sprinkles is now expected to be in superior court on July 2 for a preliminary hearing.

title: earthquake england lincolnshire humber
story: The 3.9 magnitude quake — the largest in the area in a decade — hit Grimsby around 11.15pm last night, geologists said.More than 400 reported feeling the tremors, according to the Earthquake-Mediterranean Seismological Centre.Many described feeling their houses and bedroomsviolently shaking and furniture shifting across floors as the quake struck Lincolnshire, East Yorkshire and parts of Warwickshire.There are unconfirmed reports the quake could be felt more than 60 miles away in Peterborough, Cambridgeshire.Locals in Hull, who were just a few miles from the epicentre, spilled into the street to find the source of the shaking.Pavels Gorbenko said: “My whole bedroom was shaking for up to two to three seconds.”Katie-Beth Victoria Richardson said: “My whole house shook, everyone came outside their houses to check what it was. Scary stuff!Thank god I didn’t go in to labour!”The British Geological Survey said the earthquake is the largest since February 2009 when a 5.2 magnitude tremor strike Market Rasen, Lincs.Last nights quake struck at 11.14pm at a depth of 18km, the BGS said.There are no reports of any injuries or major damage.Paul Innes told the Hull Daily Mail: It was one of the most bizarre feelings ever.I was sat watching TV on my sofa when I felt it shake the whole house.It lasted about five to ten seconds.Kirsty Reid wrote: My sofa moved and picture fell off wall! I thought I was going crazy, the dog even jumped off from me.”Paul Grimley added: Felt like someone running upstairs next door repeatedly.But some plucky Northerners have laughed off the tremors.One wrote: Literally thought my lad had dropped the remote on his bedroom carpet ....meanwhile Mrs practically running to Anderson Shelter.Paul Simpson posted a photo of his toilet roll on the floor, writing: Devastating damage in our bathroom tonight due to the #Scunthorpe #Earthquake - the loo roll fell onto the floor. Heres an actual image of the carnage.The largest known British earthquake occurred in the North Sea, near the Dogger Bank in 1931, with a magnitude of 6.1.It was 60 miles offshore but still powerful enough to cause minor damage to buildings on the east coast of England.

title: theresa may must now show shes got the chops to lead global britain out of the eu
story: There is a worrying sense of drift in Downing Street.We haven’t seen enough on vital issues at home, and our negotiations with the EU are turning into such an expensive fudge you’d think Mrs May was setting up a sweet shop for the summer holidays.There are vital votes to be fought over this week in the Commons.Win or lose, some Tory rebels will be plotting her successor.The Prime Minister must show some leadership, face down Westminster’s remoaners, and deliver a Brexit that allows this country to thrive once we leave the European Union.She must prove that she — like the 17.4million people who voted for a brighter future outside the EU — believes in Britain and what it can be.There has to be more to Theresa May than just clinging on.WE’VE heard our fair share of terrible train excuses, but tunnel trouble is a new one.It is staggering that in the 21st century, Thameslink have to change drivers in order to go through a small tunnel, as if North London has turned into Narnia.But funny as it seems, every delay matters. Not just because it holds the economy back, but because it gives privatisation a bad name.Putting the railways back into public ownership would be a complete disaster, but it is no surprise that the idea is becoming more popular.Transport supremo Chris Grayling looks derailed. His decision to sign off Thameslink’s fines for this year before they’d even run the trains is barking.He needs to get our trains back on track.BRITAIN is in the grip of a crime wave and Sajid Javid must get on top of it.The Home Secretary’s first priority should be to listen to our Beat the Blades taskforce, who today lay out their manifesto for knife-free streets.A Government that doesn’t keep the public safe has failed its most fundamental duty.The build-up to the World Cup has been more political than ever.But it is time to put that to one side. Whoever you support, enjoy the football.Who knows, it may end 52 years of hurt…Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: no gagging orders if online
story: Lord Jonathan Mance said there was no point granting gagging orders if details about cases are already widely known.In 2016 Lord Mance, 75, ruled against the British press revealing the identity of a married star involved in an extra- marital threesome.Lord Mance said: “If everybody knows the name there is no point in the law trying to shut the door after the horse has bolted.”But he said of the gagging order controversy: “That wasn’t the case in that case.”Experts warned the ruling paved the way for the rich and powerful to hush up their cheating.Lord Mance retired as Deputy President of the Supreme Court last Wednesday.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
