story: NewsFirst picture of three-year-old girl found dead at home as mum, 37, is arrested over deathLittle Amelia-Brooke Harris was found dead at a house on Friday night and police say they are treating her death as "unexplained" - while her mother Carly Harris, 37, is being quizzed&nbspShareByMirror17:11, 9 JUN 2018Updated17:40, 9 JUN 2018NewsAmelia-Brooke Harris, 3, was found dead at her home (Image: WALES NEWS SERVICE)&nbspShareGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mother has been arrested after the mystery death of her own three-year-old daughter. Little Amelia-Brooke Harris was found dead at a house on Friday night and police say they are treating her death as unexplained. Her mother Carly Harris, 37, was arrested and is being quizzed by officers over her daughter's death. Police say they were called to the family home in Trealaw, Rhondda, at around 10.20pm on Friday. And when they arrived Amelia was declared dead. The road around their family home in the former mining village has now been closed by police as part of the investigation. A spokesman for South Wales Police said: At around 10.20pm on Friday June 8 emergency services were called to an incident at an address in Trealaw in the Rhondda. A young child was declared deceased at the property and at this time the death is unexplained. Police officers investigating the incident have arrested a 37-year-old woman. She has been taken to Merthyr Tydfil police station where she is being questioned.  As a result of the ongoing investigation the main route through Trealaw - the B4278, Brithweunydd Road - will be closed until further notice and motorists are advised to take alternative routes. Anyone with any information concerning this incident and who has not already spoken to the police is asked to call South Wales Police. Neighbours in the tight knit community this morning wrote Facebook tributes to Amelia. Tyler Saunders said: My head hurts, perfect little girl was so loving kind and full of beans, little dancer. Karen Perris said: Absolutely heartbroken. Amelia you was a sweet beautiful little girl. Like a little doll. Rip darling.. fly high. You will be missed. Anna Curran said: Rip Amelia-Brooke sleep tight little angel fly high xx so sad.  Police, firefighters and paramedics confirmed were all called to the three-bedroom home in Trealaw, Rhondda, at 10.20pm on Friday night. But when they arrived at the scene little Amelia was already dead. A neighbour said: It's just so very sad and heartbreaking, we used to see her skipping down the street. A spokesman for the South Wale force said they were aware of strong concern and reaction within the local community following Amelia's death. Chief Superintendent Dorian Lloyd said: We are continuing to investigate the events that led to the tragic death of a young child in Trealaw yesterday evening and an incident room has been established.

story: NewsGirl, 9, in rehab for Fortnite addiction after becoming so hooked she WET HERSELF to keep playingHer horrified parents told how the primary school child is in intensive therapy after ­getting hooked on the apocalyptic game&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByMatthew Barbour22:17, 9 JUN 2018Updated09:30, 10 JUN 2018NewsDrawn in - Schoolgirl and the game (Image: Mirrorpix)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA girl of nine is in rehab after becoming addicted to a video game that is gripping the nation’s kids. Her horrified parents tonight told how their daughter is in intensive &shytherapy after &shygetting hooked on the Fortnite game. The obsessed primary school pupil... - Secretly got up in the night and played until dawn. - Neglected to go to the toilet because she could not bear to leave the screen. - Hit her father in the face when he tried to confiscate her Xbox gaming console. - Dozed off in class because of her night-time addiction.  Experts fear she is one of many children at risk of developing mental health problems as a &shyresult of over-exposure to the fight-to-the-death scenarios. Over 40 million have &shydownloaded the so-called &shysurvival shooter game since it was launched last July, sparking &shyrecord numbers of digital addiction. The girl’s mum tonight said: “We had no idea, when we let her play the game, of the &shyaddictive nature or the impact it could have on her mental health. She is in &shytherapy for the addiction after she &shybecame withdrawn, &shyagitated and disturbed from playing up to ten hours a day – sometimes playing until dawn, wetting &shyherself so she didn’t have to leave the screen. “This is a serious issue which is destroying our little girl’s life and someone needs to step in to ban it before it becomes an epidemic.” Fortnite has been endorsed by a multitude of top sport and music stars. The game’s most popular format is the Battle Royale in which 100 players fight each other until one is left standing. Although the game is free to download, its developers make money from hooked users who pay for in-game purchases to boost their performances.  Mum Carol, 36, said they bought their daughter an Xbox in January and shortly after she downloaded Fortnite. She and her husband Richard, who we are not picturing to protect the identity of their daughter, say it was not until mid-March they noticed &shyworrying signs. Carol said: “We got called in by her head &shyteacher asking if &shyeverything was OK. She had fallen asleep twice in lessons and her grades were slipping. “When we asked our daughter what the &shyproblem was, she became unusually &shyargumentative and aggressive, which we just put down to her hormones.” But soon the sports-mad girl started saying she too tired to go to gym or ballet classes, as well as missing the family visits to church on Sunday mornings. Noticing small but regular payments on their credit card to Microsoft, adding up to over &pound50 a month, they asked if she knew anything about this. The mum said: “Our daughter told us it could be some extras she’d paid for on Fortnite. “Of course we were furious and confiscated her Xbox. But then she lashed out and hit my husband in the face.” Despite limiting their daughter’s time on the game to one hour on school nights and two on weekends, they were still suspicious. Carol said: “My husband saw her light on in the night and found her sitting on a urine-soaked &shycushion playing the game. “I found her backside was red-raw. She was so hooked to the game she wouldn’t even go to the toilet.” The next morning they sat her down and asked her to tell the truth.  The mum said: “Crying, she told us that every night for the past two months she had waited until we were asleep and then got up to play, sometimes until 5am. “We worked out that she could have been playing for up to ten hours a day, and we’d had no idea.” The parents contacted addictions counsellor Steve Pope, who agreed to see the girl for psychotherapy. Steve told the Sunday People: “Over the last two months I’ve been &shycontacted by dozens of parents with children as young as eight showing signs of addiction to Fortnite. “I’ve been working in this field for three decades and never seen anything like it, how widespread and potentially damaging this is. “I know bright kids who will fail their exams this summer because of Fortnite, kids who are stealing from their parents and friends to pay for the extras, kids who urinate in bottles because they can’t bear to leave the game.” Experts claim it is the high-profile celebrity &shyendorsements in recent weeks that have fuelled exposure. Steve added: “You see Premier League footballers celebrating goals with Fortnite dances and it’s the biggest possible advert for kids. “It’s the perfect gateway into &shyaddiction and gambling.” Professional gamers are making up to &pound500,000 a month from live-streaming their Fortnite games for addicted children to watch. The nine-year-old girl in our &shyreport is slowly &shygetting back on track with her sports and schooling. But her mum said: “I urge every parent out there to know what this game can do, how it sucks young children in and could ruin lives.” Culture Secretary Matt Hancock has warned that addictive online shooter games such as Fortnite have a damaging impact on children. 6 TIPS TO KEEP ’EM SAFE Gaming expert Andy Robertson of the online safety group Internet Matters offers six tips for parents on Fortnite: 1 Make sure it is age appropriate The Video Standards council rate Fortnite as PEGI 12 for mild violence. 2 Monitor who your child is talking to Check the communication settings on the game to ensure children aren’t talking to strangers. 3. Manage in-app purchases on the game You will need to set up passwords on credit cards associated with the system. 4. Set time limits on Fortnite Something you can agree with your child once you understand how the game works. 5. Join in Families will get the most out of the game when parents join in and turn it from something in bedrooms to a game for the family room. 6. Stay in tune Parents should keep abreast of updates in the game to be aware of possible costs. For more info go to internetmatters.org. Prem stars boost craze Fortnite has gripped the footballing world – with players from Atletico Madrid to Cardiff City endorsing it. The list of top-flight players performing Fortnite dances as goal celebrations extends from Atletico’s Antoine Griezmann to England stars Dele Alli, Harry Kane and Kieran Trippier. Members of the England squad have openly bragged about their skills playing Fortnite. Alli, 22, boasted he is top of the Three Lions’ ranking. The Spurs midfielder, who did the game’s “floss dance” to celebrate an FA Cup semi-final goal last month, said: “I think that it’s a great way to relax and rest your body playing &shyPlayStation. “I’d say I am the best &shyFortnite player. I’ve won over 100 games. But a lot of the boys have just started playing it.  “We play in teams so it &shydefinitely brings us together.” Cardiff defender Callum Paterson has made Fortnite celebrations his speciality. And France international Griezmann regularly performs the “Take The L”dance after a goal. In the Fortnite game the dances are performed to celebrate a killing an opponent. Other celebrity fans of the game include Argentinian aces Lionel Messi and Sergio Aguero. The obsession with Fortnite even extends to watching others play.  Last month an online video of Canadian rapper Drake playing Fortnite with pro-player Ninja was watched more than 600,000 times. Ninja – real name Tyler Blevins – reportedly makes nearly &pound400,000 a month from live-streaming himself playing the game on Twitch, a live version of YouTube. Fortnite’s makers, Epic Games, have even announced a Fortnite Celebrity Pro-Am which will pair 50 celebrities and 50 pro players. Fear behind fun Internet Matters ambassador and psychologist Dr Linda Papadopoulos says: “Games can become quite addictive for children because they’re fun in the way that cartoons are fun. “A lot of apps or games act on the brain in the same way that an itch that needs to be scratched.

title: meghan markle pretty pink arrives
story: NewsMeghan Markle is pretty in pink with new curly hairstyle at Trooping the ColourPrince Harry and Meghan are expected to join members of the monarchy on Buckingham Palace's balcony to watch the RAF flypast and acknowledge the crowds&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByLucy Clarke-Billings10:24, 9 JUN 2018Updated17:54, 9 JUN 2018NewsMeghan smiled and waved to crowds in the sunshine (Image: UK Press)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMeghan Markle looked pretty in pink as she arrived for this year's Trooping the Colour to celebrate the Queen's official birthday. The new Duchess of Sussex, 36, wore her dark hair in loose ringlets as she joined Prince Harry at the traditional summer spectacle. Meghan experienced the pomp and pageantry of the event for the first time when she arrived on Horse Guards Parade with Harry in a carriage, along with the Queen's cousin the Duke of Kent. The couple were greeted by the sight of hundreds of Guardsmen in their scarlet tunics and bearskins lined up on the parade ground - Henry VIII's former jousting yard - as the event began. Harry, 33, did not travel on horseback alongside his brother William because he is not a Regimental Colonel. The Duke and Duchess of Sussex, who married three weeks today, travelled from Buckingham Palace along The Mall to cheers from royal fans gathered in the famous London thoroughfare. The Duchess of Cornwall and Duchess of Cambridge were in another carriage while a third carried Princesses Beatrice and Eugenie, the Countess of Wessex and her daughter Lady Louise.  The Duchess of Sussex wore a dress by Carolina Herrera and a hat by Philip Treacy, while Kate wore a dress by Alexander McQueen and a hat by Juliette Botterill. Camilla wore a pale blue silk dress and coat by Bruce Oldfield and a hat by Philip Treacy. Trooping the Colour is a ceremonial spectacle that brings together prestigious regiments and the families of the serving men and women in celebration of the monarch's official birthday. Stands lining Horse Guards were filled with the wives, girlfriends and parents of the servicemen who when not performing ceremonial duties are fighting soldiers.  Meghan, Harry and the other members of the royal family took their place in Wellington's former office which overlooks the parade ground. Later this afternoon, the couple will join other members of the royal family on Buckingham Palace's balcony to watch the RAF flypast and acknowledge the crowds. The Queen, who recently had a successful eye operation to remove a cataract, will watch the Trooping ceremony from a dais in Horse Guards and later inspect the lines of guardsmen in their scarlet tunics and bearskins.  More than 1,000 soldiers are taking part in the annual event with traditional display of pomp and pageantry. The colour being paraded this year is the flag of the 1st Battalion Coldstream Guards. The Duke of Edinburgh, who celebrates his 97th birthday on Sunday, has retired from official public duties and is not in attendance. The royal colonels, all on horseback, will accompany the Queen. They include the Prince of Wales, Colonel of the Welsh Guards, the Princess Royal, Colonel of the Blues and Royals, and the Duke of Cambridge, Colonel of the Irish Guards. Riding in the ceremony for the first time is the Duke of York in his new role as Colonel of the Grenadier Guards.  As with previous years, the Duchess of Cambridge and the Duchess of Cornwall sat together in a carriage. The procession is accompanied by a Sovereign's Escort of the Household Cavalry, made up of Life Guards and Blues and Royals, in their silver and gold breastplates and plumed helmets. After the ceremony the royal family will head back to Buckingham Palace and gather on the balcony to watch the RAF flypast. Among the 23 aircraft taking part are modern jets and historic aircraft, while the Red Arrows will be the finale.

title: more 500 people treated effects
story: NewsMore than 500 zombie spice drug users treated for ill effects in one prison alone last yearThe use of the substance at HMP Humber has increased 'the level of violence on the wings'&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByJohn Kelly22:27, 9 JUN 2018Updated22:38, 9 JUN 2018NewsA jail monitoring group said Spice, as pictured, and other 'Psychoactive substances continue to be a major issue' in prisons (Image: Manchester Evening News)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMore than 500 prisoners were treated for the effects of zombie drug Spice last year in just one prison. Almost a third of the 1,000 in HMP Humber claim to have got a drug habit while inside. There were 533 medical call-outs at the category C jail last year – more than 10 a week. Figures come from a new report by the jail’s Independent Monitoring Board, which said: “Psychoactive substances continue to be a major issue.” It said the East Yorks jail held a “high proportion of vulnerable individuals” and Spice increased “the level of violence on the wings”. Earlier this year prison chiefs ordered all mail to its inmates to be photocopied to prevent drug-soaked letters being delivered.  The move came after the Sunday People revealed Spice was being sprayed on to letters and even pictures drawn by children for their prisoner fathers. And nurses have been told to stop tending convicts at another jail awash with Spice – Holme House at Stockton-on-Tees – for fear of exposure to fumes. Glyn Travis, of the Prison Officers’ Association, said recently that Spice was an “epidemic” in prisons, causing violence, self-harm and suicides.

title: mum shopping tesco makes naughty
story: NewsMum shopping in Tesco makes naughty daughters 'sit down in silence' - and is applauded for her actionsLouise Palai said her daughters, Alisa, 6, and Ebony, 7, had been making too much noise during their weekly shopping trip by running around the store in Ilkeston, Derbyshire&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByNick Reid00:23, 10 JUN 2018Updated09:14, 10 JUN 2018NewsEbony, seven and Alisa, six, were made to sit in silence in Tesco after misbehaving (Image: Louise Palai/Derby )&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A mum has been praised for the way she punished her naughty daughters when they 'ran riot' in the middle of Tesco.  Louise Palai said her daughters, Alisa, six and Ebony, seven, had been misbehaving during a weekly shopping trip by running around the store and making too much noise. Furious, she made them sit with their heads down in silence in the middle of the vegetable aisle until they had calmed down.  The 35-year-old told the Derby  her tactic was better than smacking or shouting.  She insisted she would do it again somewhere as busy a shopping centre if she needed to get her kids to calm down and behave.  They don't mess about again when you make them sit in the supermarket, said Louise. They suddenly start behaving as they know everybody can see them. I don't care how old my daughters are, they need to learn to behave when they are out in public and making them have a time out wherever they may be, really calms them down and they stop messing about. Even if they were messing around in the street or in the intu centre, I would get them to do the same thing, no matter how many people are around, they would be forced to sit down and think about that they are doing. There were a few people giving me some odd looks, but I don't care what anybody thinks. This method works and it is a much better alternative to shouting at the girls in the middle of the street or smacking them like I have seen other parents do.  Louise made her youngsters sit down in Tesco , in Ilkeston, on Tuesday as they had been running round the store, making noise and being a nuisance to people.  When they failed to calm down, she made them sit on the floor with their heads down, cross legged, in silence. The children were sat down in the store for about ten minutes before they were allowed to move. Louise stated this is a method she has used at home making them sit on the stairs to calm them down. When out and about though, the youngsters have been forced to take a time out at other stores including Primark in Derby and York as well as the Albion Centre. She said: No matter where you go, there is always a step they can sit on, but if there is no step there is always the floor.

title: mum two reveals how accidentally
story: NewsMum-of-two 'accidentally' drunk-texting ex-boyfriend led her to finding perfect man - and 17 years of marriageJennie McGlashan thought she was texting her ex - little did she know, she was about to meet her future husband&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByTammy Hughes20:21, 9 JUN 2018Updated09:13, 10 JUN 2018NewsLucky day: Jennie accidentally sent her message to a stranger called Rob&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWhen lonely Jennie McGlashan had a moment of weakness and decided to text her ex, the result was totally unpredictable. Because she got her old boyfriend’s number completely wrong... and ended up finding her Mr Right. Jennie feared she might never be happy again after her relationship broke down in the same year that her father died from a brain tumour. But the 21-year-old shop worker had used her mobile to accidentally contact a total stranger called Rob – and he turned out to be the man who could &shyreally ring her bell.  Once he had answered Jennie’s &shymessage, the couple got texting, then talking. They decided to meet, immediately fell in love and then got married. Seventeen years later the couple – who now have daughters Grace, 11, and Sophia , seven – are still inseparable. “Sometimes I forget how remarkable it is,” says Jennie. “It must have been a one in a million chance, but we just clicked straight away. I knew it was something special really early on. I’m a big believer in fate.” The couple’s love story began on a cold November evening in 2001. In a bid to move on from her ex, Jennie had deleted his number but then decided to get back in touch.  She said: “I’d had quite a bit to drink and was probably feeling sorry for &shymyself, so I sent a text which simply said ‘Long time, no speak’. “I didn’t get a response. I thought he knew who it was but didn’t want to reply. It was only in the morning that I saw I had a message saying, ‘I think you’ve got the wrong number.’ “I thought it was my ex pretending he didn’t know who it was. So I texted back saying, ‘Very funny, it’s Jennie.’ “My now-husband came back on &shysaying, ‘No, my name’s Rob. You’ve got the wrong number. I live in Germany.’” Engineer Rob, from Manchester, was 28 at the time and had two phones – an English one and a German one. He said: “I swear the English one had been turned off, but when I woke that morning it was on and there was this message from a wrong number.  “I don’t think I can explain why we got speaking, but we both just wanted to keep talking.” By the time the couple had established they were strangers, they were deep in text conversation. And Jennie could not get her stranger out of her mind. She said: “I was an &shyassistant manager in a clothes shop in Belfast and I remember I kept going back to check my phone because I &shywanted to hear from him. “It was very strange.” After a couple of weeks of texting, Jennie’s friends urged her to actually call her mystery man.  They were on a night out in Belfast while Rob was in an Irish bar in Germany, with his pals. Jennie said: “My friends were saying, ‘Ring him, ring him, and see what he’s like.’ I called, but he didn’t answer and I thought he didn’t want to speak to me. “What I didn’t know was he was &shyholding his phone as it was ringing, but was too scared to answer.” Rob’s friends persuaded him to get over his nerves and call Jennie back. When he did, the couple spoke for an hour non-stop. “And since that day, we have spoken every day ever since,” said Jennie. The following month the pair finally met face-to-face at Belfast airport. They had swapped pictures and Rob spotted Jennie in the viewing gallery as he came off the plane.  He said: “I instantly knew that this was the girl I was &shygoing to marry.” The feeling was mutual. Jennie said: “It was love at first sight. Something just clicked. We met, we hugged, we started a relationship.” The couple spent three &shyhappy days together before Rob had to return to Germany. But he was back a few weeks later for Jennie’s graduation. She said: “It was such a special day and to have Rob there made it complete, especially as my dad couldn’t be there to see me.” Later Jennie was considering moving to Germany to spend some time with Rob when she reckons she got a mystic push in the right direction. She said: “I went with my mum to get her tea leaves read. “I didn’t want mine done but the woman did them anyway. She told me, ‘You’ve got a big decision to make about moving across water. I can’t tell you what to do, but it will change your life.’ I decided to take the plunge.”

title: towie beauty guru britains best
story: NewsTOWIE beauty guru to the stars left scarred after botched anti-wrinkle injection turns her life upside downBelinda Hayle’s had to sell her home to fund a new career. The semi-permanent make-up artist, 48, tells below how her world upside down...&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByDeborah Riseley19:22, 9 JUN 2018Updated19:23, 9 JUN 2018NewsBelinda Hayles' client list included Towie stars like Jess Wright and sisters Billie and Sam Faiers&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailI loved my job as a semi-&shypermanent make-up artist. I was known as “The Brow Queen” for my specialism – enhancing &shyclients’ sparse or missing eyebrows with a digital tattoo pen. My client list included Towie stars like Jess Wright and sisters Billie and Sam Faiers. Then there was singer-songwriter Lisa Maffia, Brianne Delcourt from Dancing on Ice and Olympic cycling gold medallist Joanna Rowsell Shand. I featured in Vogue and briefly appeared on The Only Way Is Essex myself. I was flown around the world to give masterclasses to other cosmetic and medical tattooists too. Best of all, I got to give &shysomething back, regularly providing free nipple restoration tattoos to cancer patients who had mastectomies. Life was good. Working in beauty, it was important that I looked my best.  So I had Botox twice a year, starting as soon as I hit 35. It felt like a minor part of my beauty regime, no more serious than getting my nails done. It was only after 10 years of treatments, in April 2015, that one Botox jab felt different. Almost immediately I felt awful, like I was coming down with the flu. The morning after, I woke to find my face felt really wrong. I couldn’t see out of one eye and gasped in horror when I looked in the mirror and saw my lopsided reflection. Over the following weeks things got worse. I felt constantly exhausted and even began to find walking difficult. I developed a tremor and struggled to hold my head up.  I found it hard to swallow, got easily confused and forming sentences was difficult. The skin on my arms became mottled and veiny and my hands turned a weird colour. They soon became so weak I couldn’t hold my tattoo pen for work. Doctors initially suspected fibromyalgia but that didn’t seem to fit what was happening to me. I felt like I was dying. In desperation I put my symptoms into Google and was immediately taken to a forum for people who had suffered Botox poisoning. It turned out I wasn’t alone. I sought out a private specialist who confirmed the &shydiagnosis, saying mine was the worst case he has seen. I’ve since learned that Botox can cross the blood-brain barrier and strip the protective sheath from your nerves. Three years on, I have had a stroke and suffer daily seizures. I’ve been given epilepsy medication to help with the seizures but other than that the NHS has said it can do no more for me.

story: NewsTrooping the Colour recap: Meghan Markle looks relaxed as she appears on Buckingham Palace balcony at Queen's celebrationsThe Duchess of Sussex fitted in perfectly as she joined other members of the royal family at the traditional summer spectacle&nbspShareByDan WarburtonLucy Clarke-BillingsKara O'NeillUpdated19:55, 9 JUN 2018News&nbspShareVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay nowNewlywed Meghan Markle took centre stage today as she joined her new family on the balcony of Buckingham Palace to honour the Queen’s birthday. Beaming Harry, 33, and Meghan, 36, enjoyed the pomp and the pageantry of the Trooping the Colour ceremony exactly three weeks after they tied the knot. The former Suits actress – wearing a Carolina Herrera dress and a Philip Treacy hat – sat alongside the Prince in his official Blues and Royals procession uniform. The Queen enjoyed the traditional ceremony to mark her official birthday but attended without Prince Philip- who retired from public duties last year and turns 97 tomorrow. It is the fourth time the Duke of Edinburgh has missed the event. Best Trooping The Colour 2018 pictures: The Queen celebrates her 92nd birthday along with Meghan, Kate, William and Harry The Duchess of Sussex has been credited with bringing the Royal Family into the 21st Century and broke with tradition by marrying away from London. However she dazzled the thousands of Royal fans who lined The Mall with her regal look as she elegantly made her way to the palace with her new husband. It was the pair’s second formal engagement since their showstopping wedding on May 19 and comes after a rumoured mini-honeymoon in Canada. The crowds whooped in delight as the Royal Air Force demonstrated their might with a flypast of 23 aircraft, ending when the Red Arrows left a blaze of red, white and blue smoke over London. But as the jets and helicopter thundered overhead, Princess Charlotte was left in floods of tears and had to be comforted by the Duchess of Cambridge – who wore a dress by Alexander McQueen and a hat by Juliette Botterill – after dropping her plane-spotting book which had been given to the children from the balcony.  Prince George, four, was joined by his cousin, Savannah Phillips, seven, daughter of Peter Phillips and granddaughter of Princess Anne, who stole the show with her antics on the balcony. As crowds sang God Save The Queen, Savannah made gestures as if she were an orchestra conductor, getting in to the spirit of the day. But the little one didn’t seem impressed with her cousin Prince George’s singing, as she placed her hand over his mouth. There was no sign of the third little Cambridge Prince Louis, born in April. Meanwhile the Queen cut a lonely figure as she arrived at the parade in an Ascot Landau without Prince Philip by her side.  The Duke of Edinburgh attended last year, but underwent a hip operation in April. He is understood to have “spent the weekend in private” after officially retiring from public duties last year. Philip – who celebrates his 97th birthday today – has missed the occasion four times in the past and was last seen during Harry and Meghan’s nuptials in Windsor on May 19. Her Majesty the Queen – who underwent secret cataract surgery earlier this year – was celebrating her 92nd birthday and attended her 66th parade as sovereign – a record unmatched by any other British monarch. She used a blanket to keep herself warm in a carriage on the way to the Horse Guard’s Parade and wore a sky blue coat and dress by Stuart Parvin and a hat by Angela Kelly. And while her husband was not present for the big day, the Queen was accompanied by members of her family as part of their roles as Royal Colonels.  Prince William rode out on horseback wearing full regalia and bearskins, and was accompanied by the Prince of Wales and Princess Anne who saluted as they entered The Mall. Also riding in the ceremony for the first time was the Duke of York in his new role as Colonel of the Grenadier Guards, taking over from his father Prince Philip. A soldier who wore a turban during the Trooping the Colour has said he hopes it is looked upon as a “new change in history”. Guardsman Charanpreet Singh Lall became the first person in history to wear the headwear during the ceremony.  The 22-year-old from Leicester said: “I hope that people watching, that they will just acknowledge it and that they will look at it as a new change in history. “I hope that more people like me, not just Sikhs but from other religions and different backgrounds, that they will be encouraged to join the Army.” A member of the 1st Battalion Coldstream Guards, Gdsm Lall’s turban featured the ceremonial cap star to match the bearskin hats. Gdsm Lall who joined the British Army in January 2016, was born in Punjab, India, and moved to the UK as a baby, said he is feeling ‘quite excited’ ahead of the event. He said: “I’m quite proud and I know that a lot of other people are proud of me as well. “It is a good feeling... there’s going to be a lot of eyes and I am going to have an influence on other people.” After the ceremony, the Royals joined more than 1,400 guardsmen and cavalry for the magnificent parade through the heart of London yesterday to honour the Queen. A former head of the armed forces was rushed to hospital after slumping from his horse during the Trooping the Colour ceremony.  Field Marshal Lord Guthrie of Craigiebank was “receiving medical attention” following the incident, the Ministry of Defence (MoD) said. The 79-year-old could be seen lying on the ground and surrounded by police officers immediately after the fall, and was then attended to by paramedics. Royal fans lining The Mall looked on in horror as the incident unfolded near the Victoria Memorial in front of Buckingham Palace. Pictures show Lord Guthrie on the ground with a pained expression on his face, as officers rush to his aid while another officer leads his horse away. Former SAS commander Lord Guthrie was head of the British Army between 1994 and 1997 and then chief of defence staff until 2001. Meanwhile, a 51-year-old woman was arrested for a public order offence after an item was thrown towards the procession, Scotland Yard said. The woman was being held at a central London police station. A Met Police spokesman said: “A 51-year-old woman was arrested for a public order offence after an item was thrown towards a procession at the Trooping the Colour. “She is currently in custody at a central London police station.” Earlier in the day a cheeky fox delighted Royal fans as they waited to catch a glimpse of the Queen during her annual birthday parade.  The creature ran onto Horse Guard’s Parade as hundreds of people began to gather for the start of the ceremony. The fox darted out from under the stands as it searched for a way into nearby St James’s Park. Trooping the Colour is a ceremonial spectacle that brings together prestigious regiments and the families of the serving men and women in celebration of the monarch’s official birthday. Stands lining Horse Guards were filled with 7,500 of the wives, girlfriends and parents of the servicemen who when not performing ceremonial duties are fighting soldiers. title: what caring prince harry said
story: NewsWhat caring Prince Harry said to "nervous" Meghan Markle on Buckingham Palace balcony to calm her nervesLip-reading expert reveals what was said between the royals during their balcony appearance for Trooping the Colour&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByMirror21:40, 9 JUN 2018Updated23:27, 9 JUN 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA lip-reading expert has revealed what caring Prince Harry said to nervous Meghan Markle on the Buckingham Palace balcony in a bid to calm her nerves. There were huge cheers as the newlyweds joined other royals in front of an excited crowd for Trooping the Colour today, but in a whisper to her husband the former actress admitted to suffering from nerves, MirrorOnline can reveal. To the general public at large, the Duchess of Sussex looked comfortable and at ease alongside Harry as she waited to curtsy to the Queen in front of the huge crowd gathered on the Mall. However it now appears she needed some reassurance from those stood around her.  Meghan was making her debut on the palace balcony to mark the Queen’s birthday celebrations just three weeks after the royal wedding in Windsor. She stood next to Harry but slightly behind future Queen Kate Middleton who chatted to Camilla as they waited for Her Majesty to arrive. According to a lipreader, at one point Harry wipes his mouth as he turns to talk to Meghan and asks her simply: Okay? His wife replies: Yeah, are you? Harry replies simply: Yeah. After asking each other if they were “okay”, Meghan also admitted to Harry that she was “nervous!” Harry replies Yes and then smiles before saying okay?    In further snippets of conversation spotted as they turned towards the camera, Harry appears to say: “Errr. When you get into it I'll tell you more later.” Seconds later, he adds: “Then there's the flypast and then we all look up to the sky.” Meghan further responds with “alright” a couple of times while continuing to smile at the thousands of people on the grounds outside Buckingham Palace. After the Queen arrived and took her place front and centre, Meghan could be seen smiling brightly over her shoulder throughout the rest of the gathering. It has been a whirlwind few weeks for the young royals, with Meghan walking down the aisle to wed Harry after a series of public family fallouts, including concerns over her father’s health. However, the former Suits star has managed to keep her nerves away from view at a series of public events - and with many more to come, she is likely to get used to the bigger displays.

title: garden gnomes google doodle launches
story: NewsThere's a new Google Doodle game with garden gnomes and you'll want to playFans of Google Doodle now have the opportunity to play a garden gnome-inspired game online all day on June 10&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByMirror23:00, 9 JUN 2018Updated00:07, 10 JUN 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email From famous faces to well-known historical figures, fans of Google Doodle are used to discovering more about some of the world’s most important people on a daily basis, but now the search engine has dedicated a day to a different sort of figure - garden gnomes.   For many people surfing the web, the tradition of an interactive game or article at the top of the Google homepage is something to look forward to, but June 10th’s topic may surprise quite a few.  It is a whole day dedicated to garden gnomes - and there will even be a game for people to play.  The bosses at Google Doodle have decided that the humble garden gnome deserves to be talked about, and, as we have a look at what it is all about, it's obvious that there’s plenty of fun to be had. The creative team said: “Gnome figures first appeared in 13th-century Anatolia and re-emerged in 16th-century Italy. “The common garden gnome originated in 19th-century Germany from the mining area of Thuringia. “Here, local craftsmen are given credit for hand-crafting the gnomes as we know them—with shaggy beards and pointy hats.  “Propelled by local myths and increased leisure time, the gnomes began to find homes in gardens throughout the country. Legend has it they protect these gardens and bring good luck.” In the interactive Doodle, you’ll learn a bit more about how the gnome is made. Then, you’ll enlist a group of gnomes to help you decorate a garden of your own.

title: dundee face competition from motherwell in bid bring simon murray back to dens park
story: Dundee face competition if they are to make a move to bring striker Simon Murray back to Dens Park.Murray spent the second half of last season on loan at the Dark Blues from parent club Hibs and said he was open to a return – but only if the Edinburgh side went with another striking option.His first choice was to try to prove himself at Easter Road after an up-and- down debut campaign there.Whether he has the chance to do that is up in the air after Motherwell moved to take him to Fir Park.The Steelmen have reportedly had a bid of £50,000 turned down by Hibs for the striker as they look to add to their attack.And that’s unlikely to be the end of any interest in the 26-year-old with ’Well expected to continue their pursuit.A number of European clubs have also been keeping tabs on him since his Dundee United days.The Tangerines, too, have made advances to bring him back to Tannadice.The lure of a return to boyhood heroes Dundee on a permanent basis would be big for Murray, though whether manager Neil McCann is prepared to splash cash on the former-Arbroath man remains to be seen.In 14 games for the Dark Blues last season, Murray managed just the three goals despite some good performances. Gaffer Neil suggested Murray was just trying too hard to shine in front of his fellow-Dundee supporters and was happy with his contribution.The Dee boss is desperate to add more threat to his side and is expected to take his time before making a move for a new forward.

title: dundee family gets together to honour special womans 106th birthday
story: When you think of the year 1912 it seems like a completely different world.But in that year Ethel Lees was born in the small village of Newtyle – and just a few weeks ago, on May 23, she celebrated her 106th birthday with her large family.Ethel was raised in a two-bedroom flat in Lorimer Street, Dundee, and later in Roseangle House as one of eight girls and four boys in the Milne family.At the age of 23, Ethel married husband John at the registrar’s office which was located at the bottom of King Street.The couple had three children together Brian, Jack and Muriel.In 1963 the couple, together with son Brian, moved to Toronto, Canada, where daughter Muriel lived, and they were joined by son Jack two years later.Tragically the family were only there for four years before Ethel’s husband died at the age of 55.Ethel stayed in Canada with her daughter until 2013 when Muriel died following a lengthy illness.Although Ethel often visited Dundee she only moved back permanently to Broughty Ferry in February, where she now lives with son Brian.Although Ethel’s hearing is starting to deteriorate at the grand age of 106, she has had no major operations and her memory is second to none as she often reflects on her time playing field hockey as a goalie or her time spent travelling the world competing in Scottish Dancing competitions.She learned to drive while in Canada and only stopped when she was 92.Ethel said: “I have been very lucky to live this long and it is great to still keep in touch with my sister Ruby who will be 99 this year.“I have a great memory and could tell you stories and memories for days.”Her sons Brian and Jack said: “With a thousand stories and memories all the family wish this remarkable woman a very happy birthday and we hope she enjoyed her special day.”

title: dundee people bookshop managers book tour to the outer hebrides
story: A bookshop manager is setting off on a 275-mile journey to the Outer Hebrides, armed with more than 600 books for school children.Robin Crawford, from Waterstone’s in Commercial Street, will travel to Benbecula in the Western Isles as the bookseller brings a two day pop-up bookshop to Lionacleit School, as part of the First Minister’s Reading Challenge.The school is the only secondary school serving Benbecula and North and South Uist and access to books is limited.The bookshop will be open to pupils, parents and the wider community, offering a selection of books in English and Gaelic.Robin said: “I am delighted to be making this journey to create a bookshop experience for book lovers on Benbecula.”

title: dundee people frankensteins links to dundee in monster new edition
story: Frankenstein author Mary Shelley’s links to the city will be celebrated by a new Dundee edition of her “monster” story, which is to be published and distributed free to local children later in the year.Frankenstein: Or, The Modern Prometheus will be released online in a downloadable format, while thousands of hard copies will also be printed.Edited and introduced by Dr Daniel Cook, of Dundee University’s English department, the book will comprise the complete 1818 text of the ground-breaking science fiction novel, as well as dozens of commissioned images produced by award-winning local comics artists.“Frankenstein is one of the most influential novels ever written,” said Dr Cook. “It is studied in schools and universities across the English-speaking world, and everyone is in some way familiar with the story of the god-like scientist and his monstrous creation.”Shelley spent two years living on South Baffin Street as a teenager, from 1812-14, after her father, William Godwin, sent her to live with the wealthy jute-producing Baxter family.This spell would influence her, as she acknowledged: “It was beneath the trees of the grounds belonging to our house, or on the bleak sides of the woodless mountains near, that my true compositions, the airy flights of my imagination, were born and fostered.”The project is funded by the Art and Humanities Research Institute.

title: dundee people friends raise cash for cuddle cot in memory of aalayah
story: A group has raised £500 with a sponsored walk over the Tay Road Bridge in memory of baby Aalayah’s fundraiser .The daughter of Kayleigh and Darren Smith spent 19 weeks at home before she sadly died last October.Her parents were able to keep her at home for the 10 days leading up to her funeral thanks to a cuddle cot they were given.The couple have since been fundraising in an effort to raise money for a new cuddle cot to be donated to the hospital.Kayleigh said: “We have now reached our target to purchase one cuddle cot and we are currently raising funds towards buying a second one in memory of Aalayah.“Our last fundraising event is a disco on Saturday at Fairfield Sport and Social Club.”Anyone wishing to purchase tickets for the disco can find information on Aalayah’s fundraiser page on Facebook.

title: dundee people from a childhood in the opera to running a music studio tristans life in music
story: The genre may have changed but the music Tristan Button grew up surrounded by still has an effect on him.The 37-year-old, who realised his dream of running a studio nine years ago when he launched Dundee Music Studios, said his father was president of the Tayside Opera for many years.&#8220There was constantly people coming around the house, other people from the opera would all come around, drink some wine and sing some songs,&#8221 he said.&#8220It was mainly classical music that I was interested in when I was very very young.&#8220If there was ever any children&#8217s parts, me and my sister would get dressed up and thrown on stage, I sure to enjoy that.&#8220There was never much singing involved, it was mostly just being children running around on stage.&#8221Tristan said he started playing the cornet when he was four or five, and then moved on to the baritone horn while he was a student at Grange Primary School in Monifieth.&#8220But I always wanted to play the trombone and they didn&#8217t have one in the music department, but eventually the must have got a bit of extra cash and got a trombone so I started playing the trombone,&#8221 he said.&#8220And I did that right thought to near the end of high school.&#8221While he trained and began working as an engineer, he started DJing electronic and hip-hop music, later moving into scratch DJing.&#8220Some of my friends had a band and my best friend had just been asked to be the drummer so he asked if I wanted to come along and do some scratching on top of the music,&#8221 he said.After a few weeks, Tristan asked if they were ok with him bringing along his synthesizers and the band kicked off from there.&#8220It was great, we had a great time doing that and the band was together for about 12 years.&#8221Spending most of his spare time being involved in music and going into so many studios, Tristan said he always had it in the back of his mind that he one day wanted to run his one of his own.He took a few business classes and looked into what it would involve, but the timing didn&#8217t feel quite right.Then in 2007, both his parents passed away within two months of each other.&#8220It kind of just turned my life on it&#8217s head,&#8221 he said.He quit his job and spent six months travelling around Australia with his future wife, before coming back to DundeeThen in 2009 he was told that a charity studio run by his friend&#8217s dad near the Marketgait was up for sale, and Tristan decided to take the chance.&#8220It was quite a big thing for me, a bit of a massive thing for me actually but at that point in my life it was a risk I was willing to take,&#8221 he said.He launched the studio, a band booked one of his rooms full time and the business began to slowly grow, but it wasn&#8217t until about a year and a half after opening that it began to turn profitable.&#8220I remember six months into it being really really worried about things, that I might not be able to keep running,&#8221 he said.&#8220But I persevered with it and it&#8217s worked out.&#8220I&#8217m never going to be a millionaire from running the studio but it&#8217s more of a lifestyle job. I get to spend an awful lot of time with my kids which I&#8217m quite grateful for.&#8221There is still a lot of hard work which goes into the studio, with Tristan and Harris, one of the studio&#8217s staff, staying up until 5am one recent weekend to prepare it for the launch of the Dundee Music Academy, but it&#8217s paying off.The Academy is Tristan&#8217s next big project and he wants to encourage more people to start playing music.&#8220We&#8217ve got big plans for the music academy and high hopes for it,&#8221 he said.

title: dundee people pictures dundee youngsters take steps to show off their urban moves
story: Hundreds of little groovers had the chance to show their moves in the city’s biggest dance festival.The festival, which took place at the Gardyne Theatre, saw approximately 600 children showing off what they have learned in their Urban Moves dance classes run by Leisure and Culture Dundee.Running over three days, the dance festival invited different Urban Moves classes to show off their skills to friends, family and other dance enthusiasts, ensuring all of the varying age groups got the opportunity to experience dancing on the big stage.“We have also now extended to evening classes for some of the more senior pupils from S1 upwards.“At the event all the kids were great – with so many children it could have been crazy but they were all fantastic and so keen to get up on the stage.“We work with them all year round to build up their confidence so there was no stage fright. They were all raring to go.”Alongside primary school groups, there was also the chance for the dance programme’s elite dancers from the Urban Moves Junior Company, Urban Moves Training Company and Urban Moves Dance Company to showcase their skills.Alex added: “It was great having the development companies perform each night too.“I think it definitely gave the younger children some inspiration on what they can do and they just loved sharing the stage with them.”The Dance Company was also recently involved in a promotional video for Maggie’s Penguin Parade, which kicks off this summer, and will be heavily involved with shows throughout the next few months.Alex Hare, dance manager for Leisure and Culture Dundee, said the three day event was “absolutely fantastic”.She said: “The weekend was full of incredible dancing and each and every dancer and member of the audience had an amazing time.“The weekend showcase is an annual event and really gives the kids a chance to show the skills they have learned throughout the year in their dance classes.“In partnership with Dundee City Council, Urban Moves goes into primary schools each week after school and teaches the kids new routines and help them develop new skills.The Claypotts Castle PS (P1-3) Urban Moves Junior Group.

title: dundee people trying to find after 73 years mervyns looking for family ties to dundee
story: An adopted man whose mother went into labour while in prison has appealed for information in Tayside as he now believes he has family ties to Dundee.Mervyn Miller, 73, was put up for adoption after he was born three months premature while his unmarried mother was in HM Prison Edinburgh, having been locked up in 1944 for shoplifting.Mervyn said he has lived a “lucky” life but, upon retirement, decided to trace his family history. He has uncovered ties to Dundee and is appealing to anyone who may have known his mother, whose birth certificate he has not found.He believes his mum, Irene Miller or Millar, was born in Canada but grew up and worked in Dundee. Mervyn thinks his maternal grandmother travelled to Canada while pregnant, but returned to Scotland shortly afterwards.He has found a cousin, Freda, and an uncle, Raymond, who live in Dundee, but neither has been able to shed much light on the mystery. Freda’s mum also lived in Dundee and Mervyn suspects she and his mum would have hung about together.He said: “It would be a great satisfaction to know what happened to her. We just can’t find a birth certificate. In a jute mill or other factory, everyone knows everyone so there might be someone in Dundee who knew my mother.”Irene ended up in Liverpool working as a prostitute but that is where the trail goes cold.His father is even more of a mystery, but as Mervyn is mixed-race he believes a man from Pakistan, India or Sri Lanka came to Dundee for the jute industry.Born with spina bifida, Mervyn spent much of his childhood at a children’s centre in Edinburgh. Aged 18, he needed both feet amputated after a series of ulcers and fevers.

title: dundee pupils attend launch of anne frank exhibition
story: Youngsters from schools across the city attended the launch of a thought-provoking exhibition that explores the life and modern legacy of Anne Frank.The display is being held at Dundee Central Library to help mark the 10th anniversary of the charity behind it.Anne Frank + You, presented by anti-prejudice education charity Anne Frank Scotland, in partnership with Dundee City Council, draws on elements from the teenager’s life and diary that have a strong contemporary resonance.It examines themes including the nature of prejudice, and the value of freedom and education.Speakers at the launch event — which takes place days before what would have been the diarist’s 89th birthday on June 12 — included Anne Frank ambassadors from Dundee secondary schools, who discussed her life and issues facing young people today.Youngsters from Baldragon Academy, St John’s RC High School, Harris Academy, Grove Academy, St Paul’s RC Academy, Craigie High School, Braeview Academy and Morgan Academy took part.Speakers at the event were Tim Robertson, new chief executive of the Anne Frank Trust, Paul Clancy, education director for Dundee City Council and Nick Hobbs, head of advice and investigations at the Children and Young Persons Commissioner’s Office.Mr Clancy said: “Anne Frank + You is a great vehicle to show off the skills of our young people in Dundee, to share a story of hope and a message of respect.“No matter your religion, race, political persuasion — everyone deserves respect, the freedom to be who they are, and the opportunity to realise their full potential.“It’s a message that sits well with Dundonians who have a long history of tolerance and reaching out to those who are oppressed.”The launch event has been organised, with support from Anne Frank Scotland’s staff, by a steering group of teenaged Anne Frank Ambassadors.Several of them are taking centre stage, delivering speeches, presentations and singing.In the last decade Anne Frank Scotland has created more than 400 such ambassadors from among the tens of thousands of young people it has worked with.Eilidh Lean, Anne Frank Scotland Project Officer said: “Our young people unfailingly amaze and inspire us through their commitment, honesty, insight and enthusiasm for their work: sharing Anne’s story and challenging prejudice within their schools and communities.”The exhibition runs until June 27.

title: dundee school praised for excellent support of pupils with autism
story: A school has been praised for its “excellent support” for pupils with autism.Kingspark, in Glenaffric Terrace, has been re-accredited by the National Autistic Society following a specialist review.Councillor Roisin Smith, Dundee City Council children and families service depute convener, has congratulated staff and pupils at the schoolShe said: “The re-accreditation shows that staff throughout the school have a consistent understanding of autism.“They have the skills and knowledge to make a positive difference to young people with the condition.“Everyone connected with Kingspark should be very proud of this achievement.“Kingspark is a centre of excellence in this area and plays an important role in training staff all across the city to support children with autism.”The report said that Kingspark provides excellent support for autistic pupils within the enhanced support area.Staff are said to have developed very strong and effective supportive relationships with all pupils.There there is also “an atmosphere of mutual respect”.

title: dundee united step up keeper search as mehmet begins recovery from knee injury
story: Dundee United have stepped up their search for a new goalkeeper as Deniz Mehmet begins his recovery from a knee injury.The London-born Turkish youth international injured himself in the aftermath of Scott McDonald’s play-off equaliser against Dunfermline on May 4.A month on and Deniz has finally going under the knife to sort the problem after swelling delayed the operation.The 25-year-old had travelled to London for the op last week only to be told he would have to wait a bit longer.That wait is over as he underwent surgery yesterday to begin the long road to recovery.Deniz tweeted today to say the operation &#8220went well&#8221 and hopes to be &#8220back not long after the start of the season ahead&#8221.&mdash Deniz Doğan Mehmet (@Deniz_Mehmet1) June 6, 2018His recovery is expected to take some time and United don’t plan to have him available for the first few months of the season.With only 18-year-old goalie Josh Donaldson on the books, the Tangerines are on the look-out for a new man between the sticks, even if just for the first half of the campaign.Aberdeen’s Danny Rogers has already been named as a possible incomer on loan to fill the gap.The New York-born Irish U/21 international has spent three seasons on loan in the Championship with Dumbarton and Falkirk and knows the division.&nbsp

title: dundee united takeover no news is good news
story: Dundee United associate director Stuart Campbell, who represents fans’ group ArabTRUST on the club board, insists no news over the potential takeover at Tannadice is good news.In a blog post he said: “Since Mike Martin was appointed chairman we’ve seen the implementation of the widely reported ‘root &amp branch’ review of everything that happens at the club.“While we expect to see many more changes reported over the next few months, changes have already been made in finance, recruitment, youth and commercial.“The chairman, directors and staff at Tannadice have been putting in long hours to bring about the changes needed that will give the club the best chance of delivering the promotion to the Premiership and the financial stability we all want.“I’m not evading the ‘elephant in the room’ but really can’t answer any of the questions many of us have on the reported potential takeover/ investment in the club.“ArabTRUST are taking the view at this stage that a lack of information is a positive sign that any negotiations are taking place in a business-like manner and when it’s possible the club will bring us all up to date with any developments.“Too many times in the past we’ve seen gossip drip fed into the media on all sorts of issues where ultimately everyone has been left frustrated and disappointed.“We must also remember any discussions of this nature will be private discussions between shareholders and potential other parties.”

title: ex dundee man etxabeguren one of two new defensive targets for dundee united
story: Dundee United’s search for new centre-backs continues apace as former Dundee defender Julen Etxabeguren and ex-Tannadice man Callum Morris have been added to their list of targets.Both are free agents, though, the Tangerines face a battle to land either signature.Etxabeguren was released by the Dark Blues last month after an injury-hit year and has returned to Spain.Whether he can be enticed back to Scotland remains to be seen, although, he did enjoy his time in Dundee.Morris, meanwhile, told Dunfermline he was leaving them to return to England but a move back to former club United might be enough for him to shelve those plans.The 28-year-old played 45 times for Jackie McNamara at Tannadice over two seasons but, like Etxabeguren, has a history of injuries.He did play 40 games last season for the Pars, however.Also on the list is former Partick man Frederic Frans.The Belgian centre-back is wanted by his former club also, as well as fellow-Championship side Ross County.Meanwhile, United have announced their first pre-season friendly.Csaba Laszlo’s men will head to Brechin City on Tuesday, July 3, kick-off 7.45pm.That sees both city clubs heading to Glebe Park in pre-season because it’s the only grass pitch in the area, apart from Arbroath.n Former Dundee United favourite Nadir Ciftci is leaving Celtic at the end of this month.Motherwell are favourites to sign the man they had on loan last season.

title: grass is worst ever
story: A dog walker has complained about the state of a local green space, after the uncut grass grew so tall it was difficult to see his pet.Vincent Leonard, 59, has lived close to Menzieshill Wood – known as the quarry – for 18 years and said the grass is the worst he has seen it.Vincent said: “The grass is so overgrown you can hardly see your dog at times. It is knee high in patches. It hasn’t been cut this year.“From what I’ve been told by environmental health, the entire quarry should be getting cut completely once a month.“I was told the whole lot of it would get done every month, and it’s not been done.“The last couple of years they have been doing what they call ‘picture framing’ – cutting the edges but not the middle – this year they just did the path.“It is that bad at the moment, it needs it all done.”Vincent said he has complained in the past and within hours somebody has visited the site to cut it.He said he walks his dog, Jack, round the quarry four times a day, and that occasionally, even when the Jack Russell is on a lead, there are times when he cannot see him.He added there are a lot of new houses being built in the area and that children come down to play in the woods.He said: “The kids are rolling in it, it’s that long. You don’t know what they are rolling in.“I have been told there is broken glass but I haven’t seen it myself.”He says he has been in touch with the council, which has not responded, and also contacted a local councillor who has also not responded.“They just planted about 70 trees there so I don’t know if that is their excuse not to cut the grass,” he added.“In the past there have been dogs hurt.“The grass has never been so bad before. I have lived here 18 years and never seen it this bad.“There is a fair bit of dog mess. I’m very frustrated.”A Dundee City Council spokeswoman said: “We are undertaking improvement works in this area, and have planted additional plants and trees. This is an ongoing project and we will be looking at ways to make the area more attractive for people to enjoy and this will involve cutting the grass.”

title: jack hamilton signing a great bit of business says derek soutar
story: Signing 24-year-old Jack Hamilton is “a great piece of business” according to a man who knows a thing or two about keeping goal for Dundee.Derek ‘Soapy’ Soutar had two spells at Dens Park, totalling eight years, and has seen first-hand how good Hamilton can be.After Soutar suffered an injury in his time at Forfar back in 2012, a young keeper by the name of Hamilton came in on emergency loan to cover at the age of 18.Watching his progress since, Soutar was delighted to see him arrive at Dundee.Soutar said: “I was very surprised Hearts let him go.“He came in on loan at Forfar when he was just 18. He was a great size, very athletic and a really good shot-stopper, great at one-on-ones and his distribution was excellent, too.“With Jon McLaughlin leaving I thought it would be the ideal chance for Craig Levein to put Jack in for pre-season.“He’s moved on, though, and Dundee have a great signing.“I worked with Jack, he’s a great lad and really down to earth personality.“I think it’s a great bit of business by Neil McCann.“He’s a good age with plenty of experience as well at Hearts and all the different levels with Scotland.“It’s a massive signing for Dundee – he could be there for years to come.“He will have to bide his time, though, because Elliott Parish did really well at the end of last season after Scott Bain left.“Every goalie is going to have times when it’s not going for you but Elliott got through that and didn’t do a lot wrong. He’ll take some shifting for Jack.“What it will do is push Parish to be as good as he can because he knows Jack will be breathing down his neck.”After a steady first season at the now renamed Kilmac Stadium, Parish will feel he’s the current No 1 at the club but the arrival of another senior goalie can spur both to excel – and that’s good news for the Dark Blues.Hamilton has represented Scotland at every age level from U/15 to U/21 and was called up to a squad by Gordon Strachan in May 2016.He didn’t get a first senior cap but Soutar reckons he can push his way back into the national set-up by impressing for Dundee.He added: “Not so long ago he was in the Scotland squad.“He maybe lost a bit of confidence last season at Hearts and being on the bench.“He’s very professional and will push himself to the max to make sure he’s ready for pre-season at Dundee.“He’s very level-headed, he’s not one for the big-time if you know what I mean, he’s not a flashy kind of guy.“I know the kind of level Jack can play at, I’ve worked with him and I think he could get himself back in the Scotland set-up while at Dundee.“Whatever fee was paid, he’ll definitely justify it.“Further down the line, he could even get Dundee a fee if he moves on so, for that reason, I think it’s a great piece of business.“Working with (goalkeeping coach) Rab Geddes every week, too, can only bring the best out in Jack.“A three-year deal gives him security and playing for a manager who wants him in Neil McCann will help no end.”The former Dundee and Aberdeen goalie, meanwhile, is still going strong with his Derek Soutar Goalkeeping Academy.“It’s still going really well,” he added. “That’s us had 38 goalies over seven years go on to play pro-youth and we’ve had one recently go out to the US for a scholarship.”Any budding young goalies can find out more on the academy’s Facebook page.

title: manchester united boss jose mourinho watches dundees former arsenal midfielder glen kamara amid transfer speculation
story: Jose Mourinho was watching as Dundee’s Glen Kamara picked up his fourth international cap in Finland’s friendly defeat in Romania.The 22-year-old has drawn plenty of interest in his time at the Dark Blues – Mourinho, however, was only there as a guest of Romanian agent Ioan Becali and stressed in an ad-hoc TV interview he wasn’t looking at players, just enjoying his time off.Kamara, meanwhile, despite only joining up with the Finnish national squad on Monday, played the majority of the second half in Ploiesti.The Finns, ranked 62nd in the world and not at this year’s World Cup, started the friendly match well but fell behind in the first half to Cristean Manea’s 37th-minute strike.In the second period, Kamara made his entrance after 57 minutes for Nottingham Forest’s Thomas Lam but almost immediately the team fell further behind.On 61 minutes, winger Ciprian Deac finished from close range to give the Romanians a home victory.Finland boss Markku Kanerva said: “The start was challenging but we looked good. We fought well and did not give up.“Of course, we should not be satisfied with this result but we did not have a full squad.“At the end, we got a little bit to attack more.“I had to think a little about the team when Pyry Soiri and Glen Kamara were only involved on Monday for the first time so they only played the second period.“There was little to be done in the last third. Romania defended the centre very well and, of course, it is a good team.”Finland play Belarus in Kamara’s birthplace, Tampere, on Saturday.

title: new rule all dundee united players must live within 25 miles of tannadice
story: Dundee United chairman Mike Martin has vowed the club will not continue to “reward failure” in a shake-up of the wage structure.Martin took overall charge of the club in March and is conducting an overhaul of how the club is run.He said: “We have put a new wage structure in place which is split between Championship and Premiership, ensuring players coming to the club know what they will be paid in the Championship but also know the earning opportunity once we are back in the top flight.“Linked to that, we have increased the reward element of total pay. In other words, we are going to reward success – and reward it quite handsomely.“However, we’re not going to reward failure. We have been very clear to the players still here, and those joining, that we expect success and are happy to pay for that success. We will not continue to pay for mediocrity.”Martin has also put in a place a rule that harks back to the Jim McLean days as he wants every player to be living within 25 miles of the city.He added: “What we are saying to these professionals is we want them to live in the Dundee area.“We don’t just want them to be part of the team but also part of the club and part of the community.“We have put in place a new rule that says players need to live within a 25-mile radius of Dundee and we believe that will be a major factor in creating the spirit and collegiate nature we want to implement.”
